story:
Hello everyone my name is Jessica Wilburn, or in the art community, known as JJ_BOO.

I am a local artist and resident of Seattle, WA, where I'v lived all of my life.

I've been fascinated by art since the age of two.

 To keep me occupied,while my mother was at work,my babysitter was a box of crayons and typing paper.

Colors exploded for me and I was enthralled by shades and hues. My fascination with colors and textures intensified when I began to notice the variety of shades in skin tones ranging form porcelain to ebony at the multi-cultural community center where my mother worked. 

I am mystified by the grandness of it all and try to capture it in my pieces.

When asked to share in the development of a character for a children's book I was invigorated. The author, Michelle and I have completed 3 books in a year.

The captivating children's book we've developed tells the story of a daycare owner named Ms.Lavender Periwinkle.

She teaches a lesson in core values, compassion,generosity and integrity to her participants. She spins a tale and engraves an uplifting message in children's hearts. 

We need funding to continue Ms.Periwinkle's journey to publication.

Our target  $3,500.00.

The Periwinkle series will impact  young readers and help develop caring and sharing behaviors. 

The vibrant colors and detailed pictures are representations of the readers, their friends and neighbors. To contribute like, share,comment  or just come to say hi visit us at:

Twitter: https://twitter.com/lavi_ms

Email: ms.lavender.periwinkle@gmail.com 

See you there!

story:
I am a Chicana artist who resides in New York City. I was raised in Northern Arizona and Southern California. I recently finished my masters of Fine art at the NY Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture. I have been working on a series of Mexican blanket paintings over the past couple years. Recently I was accepted to an artist residency in Oaxaca, Mexico. This residency will teach me traditional methods of backstop weaving. This will enable me to learn about the colors and patterns I have been painting. I will be able to create new mixed media artwork with this new skill along with learning more about my culture.

Contributing to this campaign will allow me to pay for my materials, travel costs and costs of being away from my job and home for a month. It will allow me to expand my vision and create a new group of work for an upcoming show.

Being away from home for a month means that I will have to move apartments and ship and store my things. I still have to pay all of my monthly bills that I would normally pay if I had a full time job along with travel costs, living costs and materials.

This residency will give me a chance to focus on craft and experiment with new materials in a different country and scenery which will allow me to gather new material, ideas, and motivation to make great work.

Investing in an artist is investing in a dream. It is investing in creativity and beauty and education.
Every bit counts! If you can't contribute please share this page and my website and videos to help spread the word.

story:
Who are Leeds Print Workshop?

We are a new co-operative printmaking studio opening in the centre of Leeds. As a not-for-profit, our mission is to provide access to specialised equipment and a space to work for anyone interested in printmaking. As well as catering to all the established printmakers out there in Leeds, the workshop will run classes to bring new people to the medium.

Leeds Print Workshop is all about building a creative community, and making it open to anyone.

The Leeds Print Workshop founding committee is made up of fine artists, teachers, graphic designers, illustrators and others all with one thing in common: a love of printmaking. As teachers, and as artists in the community, we’ve had the same conversation hundreds of times: printmaking is so much fun, and where can I do more of it? Once people have found a love of printmaking, it can be hard to continue to make prints solo. We want to be the resource that allows you to carry on printing, surrounded by other printmakers who can share ideas, techniques, innovations and feedback.

Anyone can become a member of Leeds Print Workshop and come to the space to do screen printing, intaglio, linocut, bookbinding and other print techniques. And if you’re new to printmaking, we will run a programme of workshops to teach you the skills.  We’ll do our best to keep costs for using the studio as low as possible. We’re not in it for the money – we just want to make a new space to keep on with the printmaking we love, and meet some new folks to make art with.

As incredible as the arts scene in Leeds is, there isn’t a space entirely given over to printmaking. Leeds Print Workshop will fill that gap, while making a contribution to the arts scene as a whole. What we’re really looking forward to is building connections with other arts organisations in Leeds so we can be part of skill-sharing across the whole city.

With the help of East Street Arts, Leeds Print Workshop has a prime city centre location. Our home will be on Vicar Lane, a ten minute walk from Leeds train station and close to bus links. The building is light, airy and unique – our favourite feature is the large semi-circular windows that let in lots of sunshine. The building is also going to be distinctive thanks to a mural on the façade by the Leeds visual arts group Goat Collective.

How can you help?

We have come as far as we have with no money. Zero funding at all! We have a building for the workshop, we have some materials and equipment, and we have people ready to teach: all through the founding committee giving their time and money, calling in favours, and the connections we already have within the Leeds creative community. 

To really make this workshop viable, we need your help. We want the people who use this workshop to have all the tools they need to make great prints.

Luckily for us, we’ve already had some furniture and equipment donated to our workshop. But we need to make some big purchases to make sure we can offer a full range of printmaking techniques. 

Donated equipment that the workshop has received so far includes:

Screenprint vacuum beds
Screenprint inks
Tables
Drying racks
Storage chests for artwork
Some letterpress type
A heat press

What the workshop really needs now:

An etching press!
A relief press!!
Inks
A screenprint exposure unit
Rollers for relief ink
Squeegees for screen printing

What will we give you?

We’ve been working hard to get you some brilliant perks for donating. Hopefully you’ll like them! Artist friends of the Leeds Print Workshop have printed special editions of their work just for the occasion. And for art collectors who like a bit of mystery, we’ve assembled grab bag packages of great prints from the best printmakers we know.

New Perk: Golden Ticket + Cinema Ticket
The workshop tickets have been really popular so we've decided to add some more, but this time we've teamed up with the Hyde Park Picture House so you will also receive a cinema ticket! You'll be able to choose a workshop from our first workshop programme which includes screen printing, lino printing, mono printing, natural dyeing and bookbinding. Take a look at the workshops on our website to make your choice.
Cinema tickets can be used for any standard screenings at the Hyde Park Picture House, excludes Leeds Film Festival screenings and live events.

Take a closer look at our amazing perks:

 

Please let us know if you can pick up your perk at the workshop rather than having it posted to you. Any money that we’re able to save on postage goes right back into our fundraising total! Scroll down to see better quality previews of the prints.

Other Ways You Can Help 

We understand that not everybody can help us financially. We’d still love for you to be a part of making Leeds Print Workshop happen, and here’s how you can do it:

  • Share our campaign! Every Like on social media introduces us to new supporters!
  • Keep an eye out for equipment up for grabs that might be suitable for the workshop
  • Sign up for classes or membership once we’re open

Thank you for your support!

story:
WE have been in pre-production for the film since June. Since then we have finalized the script, cast, crew, locations, & food. H.L. General Contractors Inc. have already agreed to donate all the food we need for cast & crew during the duration of filming. We are in need of financial support for equipment rentals, transportation, costumes, & props. * see expenses list for further details*  

How is this project unique, creative, or innovative? 

-   The concept was written by both Daniel Davila & Matt Lopes. It takes place in the not so distant future, though the year is unknown to the audience, where the ozone layer was disappearing at an alarming rate. To combat that, but to avoid human casualties, the government approved the use of Artificial Intelligence to resolve the situation (that’s more of a sub-plot that will be explored in the potential feature length version of the film if picked up by producers at film festivals). The A.I. resolved the issue, but once the government got what they wanted from them they decided to make them illegal to be free. The start of the film takes place a few weeks after the bill was passed that stated all A.I. are to give themselves up and to be furthermore regarded as government property. All cities were ransacked and the government is now searching all rural & suburban areas. A girl by the name of Samm refused to listen to this legal action and has not given up her 3 robots Xina, Orton, & Eli. Solomon (A government bounty hunter who has a deep hatred toward anything artificial) is then sent to confiscate these droids on his terms, which unfortunately includes torture and/or death. 

What goal or objective will your donations help us achieve?  

-It’s a collaboration with current Juilliard students, Juilliard alumni, outside directors and actors to tell a story that takes current inequalities in both society and in the arts and bring them into a fantastical, dystopian setting. It’s 2016 and racism, misogyny, and hate in general still exist. We want to take the viewers into a brief but complex world where we have lost all humanity. A world where hate and anger are aimed at Artificial Intelligence instead of the present day “minorities”. We believe through Sci-Fi we can demonstrate the ridiculous state that society is in by applying it to another worldly setting. This will allow the human mind to perceive it without judgement or defensiveness. We will be experimenting on artistic concepts that aren’t very popular in the Sci-Fi genre. We want to experiment with unique cinematography during action/fight sequences (long one shot scenes). We want to have in house scoring and editing to help rely only on ourselves for all aspects of production.  

How does this request relate to our overall career goals? 

-Our mission is to gain experience in the field of film making and to give opportunity to actors to add work to their reel/resume. We want to allow people like Jacob Faunce (3rd year Juilliard actor) to express and gain experience in the field of drawing/storyboarding. Allow Blair Sheppard (3rd year Juilliard bassoonist) to gain experience in making props/costumes for a film with a full concept/plot. Give actors Brandon Hall(Juilliard Alum), Justin Cunningham(Juilliard actor 4th year), Allen Tedder(3rd year Juilliard actor), Audrey Corsa (1st year Juilliard actor), Daniel Davila (3rd year Juilliard actor), Matt Lopes (Montclair BFA Acting Alum), & Sam Sunderly (High School Senior from Orlando) all scenes for their reel and experience on a professional project. We are giving outside director/cinematographer Eli Salcedo a chance to work on his first film. Daniel Davila & Matt Lopes will be making their directorial/screenwriting debut with this project. Al Lessig (3rd year BFA actor from Montclair State University) has also signed onto the film to do makeup/practical effects. After this is created we will be entering it into film festivals in New York and New Jersey in 2017. Then eventually will allow us to create a full length film.

story:
We are a group of Creative Event Management students at Arts University Bournemouth, who want to leave behind an artistic legacy and provide opportunities for the local creative community. 

  • This campaign has arisen from our collective passion for the arts and the need for more opportunities for creative people and students in Bournemouth. The R.A.W project aims to promote and expand upon the creative scene that currently exists and to act as a platform for aspiring artists across Dorset and the surrounding area. 
  • With your backing our vision will become a reality as we can deliver this project to its full potential and the event will be a celebration of creativity in Bournemouth. The mural will act as a beacon of the towns cultural identity and will  be enjoyed by many for years to come!
  • Our event will help bring all of the creatives to one place and realise what can be achieved. The interest already from our artist callouts and online marketing has been greatly received by local artists and creative groups. There is a real need for finding a creative networking hub for those within the town, and making Bournemouth something to shout about. Alongside this, students struggle to enter the real world after university and our multi-media exhibition event will also feature specialised talks and workshops that will offer advice and inspiration once they have graduated. A series of creative public art events in the lead up to the final event will bring colour, engagement and fun to the passersby of Bournemouth, invoking motivation to use creativity as a tool to increase quality of life. 

What We Need & What You Get

Your donations will go directly towards:

  • Funding the artists who will be exhibiting work at our exhibition. We are putting this event on to promote young, aspiring artists at the beginning of their careers as well as the local creative community of Bournemouth. This event will be a celebration of them and their work and so we aim to pay all of our artists a fair wage for contributing work, which will be directly funded by you.
  • We are also aiming to bring you interactive workshops that will engage you in different creative mediums such as live screen printing, stencil workshops, live painting and print workshops. We need money to pay our contributors and to buy the materials that will make these as interesting an experience as possible for you, the audience.
  • Not only this but you will also be directly funding the repainting of the mural, which is the focal point of the event. This mural will act as a cultural landmark for Bournemouth and will be a tourist attraction for years to come; however, without your support none of this will be possible.

The R.A.W Project aims to promote the arts in Bournemouth and the Southwest and this event will be a melting pot of creativity that we really want you to be a part of.

Our incentives are focused around promoting all of the artists and brands that we work with so everything you receive from our stickers to our postcards, prints and t-shirts will be designed or made by our contributors, which means it will all be original and unique. We are working in collaboration with SULK studio to bring you some unique t-shirt and sticker designs that will only be available through our Indiegogo page and on the day at the event.

However, if you aren’t that interested in receiving any of our amazing incentives (you’d be mad not to) but would still like to donate, there is an option to pay what you like and not receive anything in return, apart from our eternal gratitude. All you need to do is hit the ‘Back It’ button and enter the amount you’d like to donate.

We are applying for grants as other forms of funding however we still need to reach our target to achieve everything to make this event a success.

If we do not manage to meet our target however, then we will have to scale back so that we can only deliver the mural and the exhibition parts of the event. Of course we would hate to do this, as we want the event to be as fun and interactive for you as possible so please help us reach our ultimate goal.

The Impact

  • R.A.W project will act as a platform for creatives in Bournemouth to stand up and be counted and they will have their chance to leave an artistic legacy in the town centre. The local creative community are in many ways socially segregated in this seaside town and there is little chance for creative opportunities, skills development and networking, hence resulting in many leaving town and heading for more artistic towns and cities for better support.

    Bournemouth is already on the turn and things are looking bright for the future and we want to add to that through our project. There is large scale urban redevelopment in the town centre happening right now and Bournemouth Arts By The Sea Festival grows year on year. The Arts University has also expanded massively in recent times and we feel our event is the perfect opportunity for students and artists to integrate with the local population in a positive and constructive way, further developing relationships and public perceptions. There is a large social gap very present and events like this will help build the foundations to closing this gap. 

    If public creative projects are seen to be on the rise, it will further enhance a place of identity and attract cultural industries and investment to town. 

  • We have the experience of our entire degree behind us, plus the support of our professional tutors, local creative organisations and the Council to make this project happen in the most professional and accessible way possible.

Risks & Challenges

As event managers we pose the risk of not understanding the needs of the artists and creatives. Therefore, we are in contact with local artists and local artist development companies to always check our process and communication. That way, those that are getting the opportunities can tell us exactly what they need, and how best to positively impact the community.

Funding for our project is a huge hurdle, one that our course has prepared us for. We are always given the latest opportunities and methods to maximise our funding. Professional funding officers within the creative community, and from our university, are helping us make sure we are doing everything we can. Additionally, we have prepared plans to help our event go ahead even if we do not reach our full funding potential - with our support and training, so no matter what, R.A.W project will thrive!

Organisation is key to our project; there are many different aspects and it is essential we work to the best of our management abilities. Between our team of six, we have assigned roles to ensure that nothing gets lost or forgotten. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you aren't able to contribute, that's not all you can do!

Shout about our project as much as you can - we have attached our social media links and from there anyone can speak to us and see what we get up to. Word of mouth is essential when working with the creative community, and we want you all to talk! Networking is a key aspect of our project and therefore just you talking about it, is helping it succeed.

Don't forget, Indiegogo has share tools specifically for making this kind of sharing easy to do! 

Please share our campaign, and help real art win !!!

#realartwins

We are putting this event on to promote young, aspiring artists at the beginning of their careers as well as the local creative community of Bournemouth. This event will be a celebration of them and their work and so we aim to pay all of our artists a fair wage for contributing work, which will be directly funded by you.
We are also aiming to bring you interactive workshops that will engage you in different creative mediums such as live screen printing, stencil workshops, live painting and print workshops. We need money to pay our contributors and to buy the materials that will make these as interesting an experience as possible for you, the audience.
Not only this but you will also be directly funding the repainting of the mural, which is the focal point of the event. This mural will act as a cultural landmark for Bournemouth and will be a tourist attraction for years to come; however, without your support none of this will be possible.

The R.A.W Project aims to promote the arts in Bournemouth and the Southwest and this event will be a melting pot of creativity that we really want you to be a part of.
Our incentives are focused around promoting all of the artists and brands that we work with so everything you receive from our stickers to our postcards, prints and t-shirts will be designed or made by our contributors, which means it will all be original and unique. We are working in collaboration with SULK studio to bring you some unique t-shirt and sticker designs that will only be available through our Indiegogo page and on the day at the event.
However, if you aren’t that interested in receiving any of our amazing incentives (you’d be mad not to) but would still like to donate, there is an option to pay what you like and not receive anything in return, apart from our eternal gratitude. All you need to do is hit the ‘Back It’ button and enter the amount you’d like to donate.
We are applying for grants as other forms of funding however we still need to reach our target to achieve everything to make this event a success.
If we do not manage to meet our target however, then we will have to scale back so that we can only deliver the mural and the exhibition parts of the event. Of course we would hate to do this, as we want the event to be as fun and interactive for you as possible so please help us reach our ultimate goal.
The Impact


R.A.W project will act as a platform for creatives in Bournemouth to stand up and be counted and they will have their chance to leave an artistic legacy in the town centre. The local creative community are in many ways socially segregated in this seaside town and there is little chance for creative opportunities, skills development and networking, hence resulting in many leaving town and heading for more artistic towns and cities for better support.
Bournemouth is already on the turn and things are looking bright for the future and we want to add to that through our project. There is large scale urban redevelopment in the town centre happening right now and Bournemouth Arts By The Sea Festival grows year on year. The Arts University has also expanded massively in recent times and we feel our event is the perfect opportunity for students and artists to integrate with the local population in a positive and constructive way, further developing relationships and public perceptions. There is a large social gap very present and events like this will help build the foundations to closing this gap. 
If public creative projects are seen to be on the rise, it will further enhance a place of identity and attract cultural industries and investment to town. 

We have the experience of our entire degree behind us, plus the support of our professional tutors, local creative organisations and the Council to make this project happen in the most professional and accessible way possible.

Risks & Challenges
As event managers we pose the risk of not understanding the needs of the artists and creatives. Therefore, we are in contact with local artists and local artist development companies to always check our process and communication. That way, those that are getting the opportunities can tell us exactly what they need, and how best to positively impact the community.
Funding for our project is a huge hurdle, one that our course has prepared us for. We are always given the latest opportunities and methods to maximise our funding. Professional funding officers within the creative community, and from our university, are helping us make sure we are doing everything we can. Additionally, we have prepared plans to help our event go ahead even if we do not reach our full funding potential - with our support and training, so no matter what, R.A.W project will thrive!
Organisation is key to our project; there are many different aspects and it is essential we work to the best of our management abilities. Between our team of six, we have assigned roles to ensure that nothing gets lost or forgotten. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you aren't able to contribute, that's not all you can do!
Shout about our project as much as you can - we have attached our social media links and from there anyone can speak to us and see what we get up to. Word of mouth is essential when working with the creative community, and we want you all to talk! Networking is a key aspect of our project and therefore just you talking about it, is helping it succeed.
Don't forget, Indiegogo has share tools specifically for making this kind of sharing easy to do! 
Please share our campaign, and help real art win !!!
#realartwins

story:
Dans le contexte actuel, l'idée d'organiser une résidence de création sur l'île d'Anticosti n'est pas une coincidence. Elle vient du désir d'acteurs du milieu anticostien de faire une place aux jeunes, de regarder vers l'avenir et d'accueillir de nouveaux projets dans une perspective de développement durable. Résidence Nomade accueillera des artistes au courant de l'été qui diffuseront à travers la création, une image de l'île singulière et nouvelle, une autre vision que celle purement économique qui fait habituellement les manchettes.

C’est en effet dans un désir de poser un discours contrastant par rapport à celui, cynique, concernant le pétrole que nous souhaitons organiser des résidences de création à l'auberge de la Pointe-Ouest de l'île. Nous croyons que la création offre la possibilité de faire parler des lieux, de mettre en valeur et diffuser un message positif ou critique. Résidence Nomade se veut un projet axé sur l’avenir et la pérennité de la vie sur l’île d’Anticosti.

Anticosti a longtemps été délaissée. Il s'agit pourtant d'un milieu naturel unique, où l'on côtoie le bassin géologique le plus vieux du monde, des fossils retraçant l'histoire de la vie sur terre ainsi qu'une faune et flore unique. C'est un territoire qui donne l'impression à celui ou celle qui le traverse que personne n'y a foulé les pieds: un des rares endroits où l'on peut encore observer le silence, une impression d'absence d'activités humaines.

Cette année nous allons opérer l'auberge de jeunesse de la Pointe-Ouest, grâce à la générosité de la municipalité d’Anticosti. Nous offriront des tarifs d’hébergement accessibles à quiconque désire passer du temps sur l’île d’Anticosti. Ces revenus aideront à financer les activités de résidences de création et à couvrir une partie de nos frais d'exploitation. Nous créerons ainsi un lieu de rencontre entre artistes émergents ou établis appelés à côtoyer les habitants de Port-Menier.

Quant à la maison de l’assistant gardien, voisine de l’auberge, elle sera réservée à la mise en place de résidences de création pour plusieurs artistes tout au long de l'été 2017. Nos activités culturelles amèneront du renouveau et du dynamisme sur Anticosti et la médiatisation de notre projet ainsi que la diffusion des oeuvres donneront envie à d'autre de découvrir et protéger ce lieu qui nous tient à coeur.

Contexte géographique unique.

Le positionnement de l'auberge donne l’impression d’un isolement total.  Elle est située sur la pointe la plus à l'ouest de l'île, entourée par le golfe du Saint-Laurent, le phare dialogue avec d'autres phares de la Côte-Nord et de la Gaspésie, seuls indices de civilisation outre les navires qui voguent au loin.  À une trentaine de kilomètres du village de Port-Menier, nos installations sont privées du réseau d’électricité public ainsi que des moyens de communications comme le cellulaire ou internet, idéal pour se déconnecter, pour décrocher.

Pourquoi avons-nous besoin d’argent ? 

Nous sommes dans les dernières étapes de création de notre personne morale sans but lucratif et n’avons pas accès au financement public pour notre première année d'existence. Jusqu'à maintenant, nous avons travaillé bénévolement à l'élaboration de notre projet. Or, pour que le projet fonctionne correctement, nous avons besoin d'un salaire pour bien commencer la mission que nous nous sommes donnée. Nous souhaitons également offrir un cachet à un-e artiste en résidence et aurons à faire face à des frais importants dans le cadre de nos activités d'auberge. Il est donc essentiel pour nous d’avoir un fond de base sur lequel nous pourrons fonctionner au début de nos activités.

C’est ensuite les revenus de l'auberge qui financeront nos activités tout au long de l’été. 

~

Résidence Nomade se donne pour mission:

-De mettre en place des espaces de création pour les artistes de la relève ou établis dans différentes régions du Québec ou du Canada, hors des grands centres urbains.

-De mettre en place des lieux de rencontres entre artistes de la relève ou établis et les citoyens locaux où se déroulent les résidences. 

-La mise en valeur du territoire québécois et canadien ainsi que la stimulation de la culture en régions, hors des grands pôles culturels urbains.

-Favoriser les rencontres et le partage entre artistes et les populations autochtones et non-autochtones.

-Bâtir une programmation culturelle pour la communauté hôte lorsque Résidence Nomade occupe un lieu.

-La mise en valeur du patrimoine historique des régions éloignées du Québec et du Canada.

 

Pour réaliser ce projet et soutenir nos artistes, nous sollicitons votre contribution! 

Un grand merci,

Tom Demers et Karine Locatelli

story:
Often drawing on the walls as a toddler, my flair for art and design developed at an early age. My passion is creating captivating visuals and authentic experiences. Shopping for the perfect gift, I was disappointed in the lack of options for African-American women with curly tresses. I wanted something that would bring a smile to my friends and family face, but it didn’t exist. Faced with this dilemma, I decided to create my own and Curly Contessa was born. My hope is to bring diversity to the marketplace of novelties and gifts.

I envisions inundating the marketplace this holiday season with riveting illustrations that will set a new standard for gift wrap. Curly Contessa gift wrap blurs the line between fine art and holiday décor to create an emotional connection that captivates customers. I am seeking investments to help make my vision a reality.

Your purchase  will allow me to create a product that transcends holiday décor. This product will set new standards for holiday cheer and inclusivity while instilling pride in African-American culture.

Help me fund the gift that keeps on giving, a smile, and spread holiday cheer!

Please visit www.CurlyContessa.com to purchase wrapping paper. This fundraiser has ended.

story:
In order to produce this documentary and book, I plan on conducting a research trip in Paris and attending exhibitions there while I also visit multiple galleries. The flight to Paris has already been paid for. I am especially excited to see the Mucha Museum and study the art of Alfons Mucha, but in order to do this right, I need to raise some start-up capital.

This is where you come in, friends. I am looking for $5000 to cover my operating costs, the costs of printing the book, the costs of launching the book, and the costs of paying for food and accommodations while I am in Paris and Prague. As a thank-you, I am offering some exciting rewards to you, my valued contributors, including prints of masterworks in the art nouveau style.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and help me reach more potential donors!

story:
Who Are We?

We are artists, architects and designers from 5 different countries who met at the San Francisco Art Institute several years ago. We are collaboratively designing and fabricating a large immersive installation that will be exhibited at the Headlands Center for the Arts, an interdisciplinary art space in Northern California.

 

What is our Work About?

As Though It Rained From Stars is a site-specific pavilion formally inspired by the starry dome of a 15th century Islamic bathhouse in the abandoned city of Mandu, India.

Themed along questions of desire and longing, this immersive art installation is both a tribute and a reckoning to the poetry, beauty, power and darkness of present times. 

This art work is multi-sensory and interactive. Engaging with the gut, we pose an impossible question - what it would feel like to have your desires reflected back at you in a physical space?

 

 

How are we Fabricating this?

We have been working on this project since 2016, and are now near completion. 

We started with dreams and drawings. We built models and prototypes. We experimented with shapes and forms. We created 3D models. We CNC router cut 6 unique molds. We cast them each 8 times in polyurethane rubber. We built a wooden structure to hold the rubber together in shape. We joined the structure with hinges.

We are always thinking about the space and the audience.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to fabricate this project. While we have a dedicated and highly skilled team building this piece, we need funding for the polyurethane rubber which will make the cilia soft, tactile and interactive. Additionally, we need funding for purchasing the birch ply that will be used in the structure, hinges and hardware to put the panels together, and lights to backlight the piece.

We have awesome perks for those of you who believe in our work and contribute to our campaign! Be on the gratitude list when the pavilion is installed. Receive designer T shirts and posters. The coolest one yet - be a part investor in the project and receive future payouts!

For those who cannot make it to the event, you will be treated to a full 3D 360 experience of the show, provided free of charge so that you can experience the full scale of the installation. 

 

 

 

The Impact

The work we hope to display will inspire you, create visual and sensory hallucinations, and convey the beauty, geometry and sublime desire implicit in historic domes. 

"The hot water rose as steam through the double wall cavity in the Islamic bathhouse, and fell through the starry voids that formed the geometry of the dome. And my guide told me, that in stone they cast that poetry - as though it rained from stars.. I wish I could share that beauty with you - you could feel what I felt then, that would be all that mattered." - Supermrin

As Though It Rained From Stars will be on display in the Project Space at the Headlands Center for the Arts from May 13 - May 31 2018 with an opening reception on Sunday, May 13th, from 2:00pm - 5:00pm. Entry is free and you're invited!

In the past we have run successful campaigns where we deliver on the promises we make while creating the vision the artists intended.

Distance, 2017 50' x 8' installation, stereographic wallpaper, wall molding

Encounters at the End of the World, 2017 50' x 30' installation, dry ice, wood beams

Willing, 2016 50' x 30' installation, laser cut acrylic.

 

About the Team

Mrinalini Aggarwal (Supermrin) - Creator
Supermrin is an artist and arts organizer of Indian origin working at the intersections of architecture, art and design. She led research and design at Abaxial Architects, India for 8 years before moving to California. She served as visiting faculty for the department of Exhibition Design at the National Institute of Design, Ahmedabad, and has facilitated workshops on public art, place-making and community building. Supermrin is the recipient of the graduate fellowship at the Headlands Center for the Arts, Sausalito and is also a 2018 fellow for the Emerging Arts Professionals, Bay Area.

Rahil Alimohammad - Producer 
Raised in Chicago, Alimohammad is a director, producer and writer in over 25 short films, commercials, TV pilots and music videos. He is the founder of a production company, DeBun Films, and the Carcosa International Film Festival. He currently attends San Francisco State University.

Jayden Romay Ruiz - Design Engineer
Jayden Romay is an artist and designer from San Miguel de Allende, México. He has exhibited work in Mexico and the United States, and has worked as a freelance fabricator for over 6 years. With a predilection for both the visual arts and STEM subjects, Jayden specializes in projects that build significant relationships between art, design and technology.

Ivan  Villareal - Artist Assistant
Born and raised in San Francisco, and of Mexican heritage, Ivan has been working in the arts for the last two years. His patience and skill enable him to work on painstaking aspects of the artistic process. He specializes in detail oriented work including mold making, installation construction, wood finishing, and custom fabrication.

Elizabeth Rose Lou - Marketing
Elizabeth Rose Lou is a San Francisco-based feminist artist and writer. Born to immigrant parents from Shanghai, China and Holbæk, Denmark, respectively, Rose graduated from New York University and spent three years working for New York-based artists, commercial art galleries and non-profit art centers including Michael Alan, Katherine Bauer, Galerie Richard, and Dumbo Arts Center. Since living and working in the bay area, Rose’s work addresses spatiotemporal materiality within the moving image, blurring the boundaries between physics, feminism, and politics. Her Dual Degree MA thesis in the History and Theory of Contemporary Art was titled Spacetime in Flux: Contemporary Intersections of Art + Physics.

Lucien Jeanpretre - Artist Assistant
Jeanprêtre grew up in Switzerland and worked as a magician, as well as in the stage and the circus as a scriptwriter, set designer, juggler and actor. Influenced by a minimal and conceptual aesthetic, his cross-disciplinary practice involves installations, performances, drawings and games.

Ashveta Budrani - Communications
Budrani is a photographer with a background in mechanical engineering and art direction. She is presently pursuing an MFA degree from the New School, Parsons.

 

About the Venue

Headlands Center for the Arts is a multidisciplinary, international arts center dedicated to supporting artists; the creative process; and the development of new, innovative ideas and artwork. The campus comprises a cluster of artist-rehabilitated military buildings, just north of the Golden Gate Bridge at historic Fort Barry in the Marin Headlands, a part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area.

As Though it Rained from Stars has been inspired by the unique formations of land, air and water at the Headlands.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word about this project. Find us on instagram, and facebook, share our story with your friends!

Ivan  Villareal - Artist AssistantBorn and raised in San Francisco, and of Mexican heritage, Ivan has been working in the arts for the last two years. His patience and skill enable him to work on painstaking aspects of the artistic process. He specializes in detail oriented work including mold making, installation construction, wood finishing, and custom fabrication.
Elizabeth Rose Lou - MarketingElizabeth Rose Lou is a San Francisco-based feminist artist and writer. Born to immigrant parents from Shanghai, China and Holbæk, Denmark, respectively, Rose graduated from New York University and spent three years working for New York-based artists, commercial art galleries and non-profit art centers including Michael Alan, Katherine Bauer, Galerie Richard, and Dumbo Arts Center. Since living and working in the bay area, Rose’s work addresses spatiotemporal materiality within the moving image, blurring the boundaries between physics, feminism, and politics. Her Dual Degree MA thesis in the History and Theory of Contemporary Art was titled Spacetime in Flux: Contemporary Intersections of Art + Physics.
Lucien Jeanpretre - Artist AssistantJeanprêtre grew up in Switzerland and worked as a magician, as well as in the stage and the circus as a scriptwriter, set designer, juggler and actor. Influenced by a minimal and conceptual aesthetic, his cross-disciplinary practice involves installations, performances, drawings and games.
Ashveta Budrani - CommunicationsBudrani is a photographer with a background in mechanical engineering and art direction. She is presently pursuing an MFA degree from the New School, Parsons.
 
About the Venue
Headlands Center for the Arts is a multidisciplinary, international arts center dedicated to supporting artists; the creative process; and the development of new, innovative ideas and artwork. The campus comprises a cluster of artist-rehabilitated military buildings, just north of the Golden Gate Bridge at historic Fort Barry in the Marin Headlands, a part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area.
As Though it Rained from Stars has been inspired by the unique formations of land, air and water at the Headlands.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Help us spread the word about this project. Find us on instagram, and facebook, share our story with your friends!
campaign_city: Headlands Centre for the Arts, United States

story:
Dear supporters, I am Ursula Carrascal from Peru and this is my story.

​“I dance for love of the Earth. My wings are the heart that flutters to the moon where my grandfather, the eagle, watches me to guide my path.

I breathe in the cooing, the voice, the river that turns into tears. I am the seed, the root, the trunk, the branch. My dance is the result of my deep and genuine commitment to the mother that feeds my essence, the echo of existence”. 


I am a woman that belongs to the world, where my blood is the water that feeds the oceans , rivers and lakes. My connection with the Earth is born since my legs danced for natural love.

I have sung to the moon, to the stars and to my heart. In my written letters are my claims for the pain we cause to the Universe. I declare myself a fighter of my own existence and of the existence of humanity and of those who live in it.

My life is the canvas of my work deeply connected with my ideals that are my way of life. Years of environmental commitment expressed in dances created and driven from my innate creativity, not by ego, but by love.

Lalety I was invited to be part of  the 8th annual Summer Institute of Dancing Earth  a powerful gathering space for international indigenous cultural fartist-leaders, from countries such Canada, New Zealand, Australia, Peru, Guåhan, Mexico, Norway, and places in the US and the Caribbean. 

There are only 12 spots for this summer intensive called Renewal & Regeneration: of Energy, Culture, Art, to be held at the Jicarilla Apache Reservation, Ghost Ranch, and the Academy for the Love of Learning in New Mexico (USA). 

Being part of the 8th annual Summer Institute of Dancing Earth is a beautiful possibility to find myself in essence with other magical and powerful beings who feel that the world still has the possibility to heal with dance.

It is also the gift of discovering my origins of my tribal dance and of my ancestors in the silence that I feel my life needs more than ever. Deconolise and deconstruct me is perhaps one of the biggest challenges I have to follow the path that the Inti, the sun father, has given me. I have a mission, to become old at the right time, but with wisdom so that our peoples transform the energy of death, into the energy of life, where the sun, water, wind are the engines of human development , but with environmental justice.

However, being an environmental fighter means having great challenges and difficulties to face. In my country Peru, taking on the role I have of using art and community mobilization for the healing of the Earth involves facing interests and renouncing economic possibilities that do not go with the values ​​I firmly defend. During the last year I had to give up my job as a university professor for betting on a methodology in education based on creativity and environmental empathy. On the other hand, I had to renounce a business partnership due to harassment and psychological violence by my partner. Being a woman, ecologist and fighter has great consequences and I have been without secure employment for more than a year. I am not able to afford my participation for myself. 

When I received the invitation to be part of the Summer Internship a light of hope was born in me. I felt that all was not lost, that the possibility of renewing energies, sharing my work with other wonderful beings, could be given. For this reason, it is extremely important to ask for your solidarity support with this cause that will help not only those who write these lines with humility, but also indigenous children of the community of Bena Hena in Ucayali (Peru),  with whom I will make an indigenous contemporary dance laboratory on climate change. The results will be part of a research I am doing on the subject to be shared in New Mexico and be part of my Thesis about indigenous cultural resistance using contemporary dance.

 

Would you like to know a bit about my background...

I am the Director of the Minaq Ecodanza, a Peruvian platform working since 2008 in creating environmental awareness through movement, therapy and visual arts. As a journalist, choreographer and ecologist I has worked intensely more than 20 years ago in promoting sustainable livelihoods in a lovely and creative way. My life experience as a leading performer has included the research and execution of indigenous children contemporary dances related to climate change and natural ecosystems (Amazon). I have worked for years with people impacted by lead and debris contamination.

During the year 2000 I won the International Ecology Peace Prize (Bolivia) and during 2017 was recognized as The Woman for Environment (University of Callao). I has worked with national and international associations in networking and organizing events with regional and global leaders allowing me to be in 22 countries as speaker and leading workshops. Thanks to schoolarships I have been trained in social therapy by the East Side Institute (NYC) and bieng trained as well in becoming in a dancer therapist. I has studied a Master in Gender, Policy and Society with FLACSO. 

Please watch some of my videos

Chillon the dancing river: a video dance about Tipsimuyo and her daugther Pachamama, who gives birth to her son the river chillon.

Direction and main choreographies Ursula Carrascal.

Global Water Dance Callao 2017

Producer/coreography local dance: Ursula Carrascal

story:
A Dream becomes a Sculpture

Luna Flora came to our Lead Artist in a dream. In her own words:

"2017 was the beginning of a new nine-year celestial cycle, noted both as “The Year of the Goddess Awakening” and “The Divine Feminine Returning”.  As I reflect back on 2017, it is undeniable that there is truth in that idea.  Women’s issues currently sit at the top of every news cycle. The cultural conciseness of the world has shifted it’s attention to #metoo, harassment in the workplace, violations of the body and mind, self worth and safety, gender identity and orientation.  In my own life this year has been one of deep healing of personal traumas from my childhood, teens and twenties.  I ventured out on a six week solo journey across the US for the 1st time to pursue a life I knew I deserved, a life filled with human connection, creativity, and the freedom to begin releasing the wounds of my past.  That trip concluded with my virgin year at Burning Man.  This was a life changing experience and while reflecting back on my 2017 experience, Luna Flora came to me in a dream. It is the culmination of my own twenty yearlong journey identifying as an artist represented in a single interactive sculpture."

A Network becomes a Team

Our team of 11 has been assembled from an extended network two communities, one fostered by years spent in the Burningman and the second through the Urban Laboratory at Arcosanti. With a lead artist, an engineer, a project manager,  a lead builder, seven fabricators, and a documentarian, we intend to grow the seed of Luna Flora into a 15 foot tall installation on Playa, creating a documentary about the process along the way. 

Now more than ever Burner artwork is in the cultural consciousness. Part of this elevated awareness can be attributed to the rise of social media, the long term installation of Burner artwork in cities across the United States, and the massive and well received exhibition at the Smithsonian in Washington D.C.

Through the building and documenting of our sculpture and it's eventually finding a permanent home off Playa, we hope to further the narrative that Burner art can make a meaningful impact to the world at large.

Our contributors are our collaborators. A dream only manifests as reality with the help of a community. With your contribution you will be invited along to come on this journey us.

What we're asking for...

Tier 1 Funding

$12,000

We need your help raising an additional $12,000. Tier 1 Funding for us has already been met in the form of $12,000 generously provided by a Burningman Honorarium grant to gets us started with the purchase of fabrication equipment, supplies, and transportation to Playa for Luna Flora. That having been said, several large purchases have already started to stretch our budget to an uncomfortable degree. Which brings us to...

Tier 2 Funding

$20,000

Meeting our Tier 2 Funding goals will ensure that our stretched budget from Tier 1 doesn't snap on us and risk the future of the project.

Beyond that goal, a project like this requires specialized skills and a unique personal investment from those who are collaborators to be willing to dedicate hundreds of hours of their time to it. For that reason, we have assembled a team of crew members from both the Southwest and East coast, all of whom understand that Luna Flora is a labor of love. 

To thank our crew for their work we would like to be able to pay for the cost of their trips out to Arcosanti for our build dates, plus attempt to cover personal transportation to and from Playa.

Tier 2 funding will also allow us to have a little bit of extra money set aside for any unforeseen circumstances (accidents, tool malfunctions, budget overrun, ect.) so that none of our artists have to shoulder the heavy financial burden that those scenarios can cause.

Tier 3 Funding

$24,000

Tier 3 funding is our ultimate goal. This amount will allow us to cover our costs entirely, plus offer a small stipend to the artists who have made a contribution to this project, including our graphic designers.

Any money raised beyond our tier 3 goal will be used to enhance the quality of the documentary being made about this journey, plus look into ways we might host that documentary online for free to the public, which will be our way of giving back to the community and a way to offer the world at large chance to see how much work goes into bringing a dream into reality in Black Rock City!

What you get?

We have a number of unique rewards to offer for your contribution to Luna Flora. In addition to the more traditional campaign swag items like stickers, t-shirts, and social media shout outs, we are offering one of a kind moon pendants, hand crafted by our Lead Artist, for all donations $50 and above. 

Shooting Star $100 donors get everything from the levels below plus a personal thank you on Playa during our Monday night "Celestial Bodies" launch party at the installation. 

For the Solar Flare $250 donor range we are offering 3 individuals a one hour session with intuitive reader Rob Jackson. Our second perk in this category is an on Playa massage in our village, The Avant Yard, using "the human buffer" a device which can only be comprehended totally through first person experience. 

$500 Solstice Level donors will have their names featured on a plaque located in front of Luna Flora durning the Burn so that the entire community can appreciate the generosity of your contribution.

Heavenly Body Level $1000 donors will have their name featured on the Playa plaque, plus one of three unique bronze cast 16" sculptures of Luna Flora, made in our foundry at Arcosanti.

Super Nova Level $2500 donors will be invited to spend 2 nights in the Arcosanti AirB&B plus will be treated to a dinner with our Lead Artist cooked for them by our Project manager.

On top of those perks, we would also like to offer anyone within the Super-nova range two inscribed and personalized bronze plaques, one that will be yours to keep and one that will live with Luna Flora in her permanent off Playa home as a way of acknowledging your generous contribution to her creation.

The Impact

Every human, regardless of gender identity, has qualities of the feminine (yin) and the masculine (yang). The hope is that Luna Flora will inspire intriguing thoughts and conversation around this maintaining a healthy relationship to this balance in ourselves, our peer groups, and the world at large.  Like the moon, we live in a constant state of liminality or transition, settling only for a moment before moving into the next phase of life, growth, and creation.  This progression can be observed in our physical bodies, thoughts, relationships, and creative processes.  We hope this piece will inspire citizens to pause for a moment and reflect on the wonders and challenges of the human experience. 

How else can I help?

We understand that not everyone has the financial resources to donate to a crowdfunding campaign. Sharing our campaign on social media and passing it along to like minded folks is a gift that we appreciate! We invite you to also follow our journey on Instagram.

story:
Hello team!

My name is John Bodine and I am expanding my vision of Metamorphosis, a mobile art piece I first took to Burning Man in 2015. The aim of the campaign is to help me make this dream a reality, adding a net of 4000 LEDs to each wing for a total of 8000 individually controllable lights on each wing!

Will you help bring this magnificent flying machine to life?


What I Need

To make this work I' will need lots of lights and lots of power. Specifically...

 - 8000 lights: 320 strands of 25 lights/strand (WS2801 LED Pixels)
 - 6 power supplies: 55A 275W power supplies
 - Power: Honda 2000i generator
All funding will be put towards lighting this love! If I hit half the goal I'll have have the lights, one way or another she will again fly the playa, this time at night!


The Impact

On November 7 2010 I first conceived of the idea of a pedal-powered art project that could literally pass "over" people walking or riding their bike. Last year I made half of the dream, building the frame and wings and taking it to Burning Man for the first time. She worked fantastic and was well received by those who saw her or rode with me. Now it's time to make her really shine, lighting her so she can play at night. 

This year she will also include an electric motor, making it possible to travel greater distances and enchant more of the 65,000 people who descend on the Black Rock Desert every year.

Will you be part of this dream?


The video attached is only 200 lights, now imagine 4000, now double that. That's the vision! Can we make this happen? You bet we can!


Risks & Challenges

I can do this, but it will take work and work that I'm ready for. Starting April 2016 I will be updating the framework for the wings, making it easier to assemble and ensuring safety and stability. I have already built a test net of 200 LEDs that can be controlled via an iPad, changing the colors and patterns with ease.

This campaign will allow me to purchase the lights necessary to build a net that will attach to each wing, with every knot of the net an LED that can be controlled from the iPad. 

At this time the greatest risk is the funding. Second to funding is ensuring the power is distributed correctly to the lights, I've got a plan in place for this and I have reached out to several other makers who have built large scale LED art projects, I have received great support from them and can reach out as the project progresses. Friends and family are geared up and ready to help build, I just need you!

I have the time and just need your help with the funds! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to help? Would you still like to help and live in the Bay Area? If so, let me know and I'd welcome you to a work party as the project progresses!

story:
Hi There,


My name is Kingsley and I am the writer of the short film Loss. This was a project that started initially as a little homework for myself. Being an actor can be difficult and finding opportunities to be creative and expressive in the art can be hard to come by and that is why I have decided to make this film. I believe in artists giving themselves the opportunity to create.

I'm hoping that on completion of this project we can go to film festivals, and in regards to the funds, whether we reach our goal or not, it will all go to the project as we seek to do create this film by every means possible.

We would love for you to join our journey, share with your friends and spread the word.

We also have several perks for donating. Thank you for checking out our campaign. It means the world.

story:
Sobre mí (english version below)


Autorretrato en estudio. 2016 / Self-portrait in Studio. 2016

Soy Héctor Eliazar, un artista multidisciplinar dominicano. Estudié ingeniería civil en la UNPHU y empecé a trabajar en ese campo, sin embargo lo abandoné para dedicarme al arte que es mi verdadera vocación. Me formé como fotógrafo en la EAF de Buenos Aires, en donde comencé a mostrar mis primeros trabajos. Al volver a Santo Domingo en el 2013 gané una mención de honor en la Bienal de las artes visuales y en el año 2015 fui galardonado con el Premio Expositivo del Premio Joven del Centro de la Imagen de Santo Domingo. Este premio consiste en la cesión del espacio y curaduría por parte del Centro, pero no contribuye en la producción de la obra, marcos, transporte, invitaciones, gastos de inauguración y performance.

La exposición tendrá lugar en el Centro de la Imagen de Santo Domingo durante el mes de septiembre, dentro de la VI edición de Photoimagen. Será mi primera exposición individual.

Post Dembow Tempo 

Dar forma a un proyecto basado en la fotografía es un reto, pues si hay una disciplina artística por la que tengo amor y pasión, es esta. Inicié este viaje en búsqueda de una identidad estética y conceptual, tomando como referencia elementos del lenguaje  fotográfico y cinematográfico junto al sincretismo, muy presente en el día a día de esta sociedad y en lo que para mí es su manifestación más compleja: la construcción constante de nuestro creole.



5’6’’ shoes, 2016. Fotografía. 30 x 30 cm. / 5’6’’ shoes, 2016. Photograph. 30 x 30 cm.

La muestra se compone de cinco instalaciones fotográficas y de video. Durante la apertura habrá un happening con música en directo, en la que contaremos con un palero en la percusión y la colaboración desde Bruselas de  dø√∑ Ç@K∑::: en la música electrónica. Los elementos que llevarán los actores (indumentarias-libros-magazines-fotográficos) serán posteriormente parte de una de las instalaciones. 


Thomas, 2016. Portada/contraportada del LP #3, Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62,5 cm. / Thomas, 2016. Front and back cover of LP #3, series Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62.5 cm.



Peyton y Nicole, 2016. Serie Vogue Karibe. 31 x 62,5 cm. / Peyton y Nicole, 2016. Series Vogue Karibe. 31 x 62.5 cm.

En este tiempo las cosas suceden tan rápidamente que se le da más importancia a lo desechable. El valor del objeto que perdura por su sello personal me seduce, y es por ello que he querido rescatar esos iconos de una tecnología anterior que nos abrieron los sentidos a ver el mundo y las artes de otra forma. Los discos de vinilo, VHS, cassettes, álbumes, libros y revistas, los transformo en instalaciones fotográficas y de video, tratando de rescatar la esencia que me transmitieron, convirtiéndolos en piezas que no son lo que parecen.

 Karakashi kollection, 2016. Portada/contraportada del LP #7, Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62,5 cm. /Karakashicollection, 2016. Front and back cover of LP #7, series Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62.5 cm.


Mezcla, en eso se basa Post Dembow Tempo. Ver como negamos una cultura que baila con otra, reivindicando a la vez un pasado en común, donde nos corresponde redescubrirlas y contar nuevas historias, que, en mi caso, más que realistas las prefiero como la mezcla característica de esta isla: un dembow que se compone y se desconstruye entre lo absurdo y lo post-conceptual.

Aki Abajito, 2014. Interior del LP #7, serie Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62,5 cm. / Aki Abajito, 2014. Inside cover of LP #7, series Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62.5 cm.


Lo que necesitamos 

Para la realización de la exposición necesitamos un  total de 5.300 US$:

  • Impresión de fotografías
  • Enmarcado
  • Producción de las instalaciones (ebanistería y herrería)
  • Producción del vestuario de los performers
  • Actores 
  • Catering de apertura
  • Los músicos
  • Transporte de las piezas desde mi estudio en Samaná
  • Grabación y edición de la acción para documentación

El éxito del proyecto dependerá del logro del objetivo, Algunas piezas fueron excluidas para no tener una meta económica muy elevada que frustrara nuestras expectativas. Sin embargo, hemos flexibilizado la meta y adaptaremos la propuesta a la recaudación final. Ojalá vuestros aportes superen la meta inicial y podamos realizarla con todos los elementos con que fue concebida.

y lo que obtienes

  Creo que se puede ser artista y vivir de la autogestión. Algunas piezas que son parte del proyecto - fotografías, collages, plástica- son parte de las recompensas que ofrezco. Espero que os gusten.

Lineisy, 2016. Serie Vogue Karibe. 28 x 35 cm. / Lineisy, 2016. Series Vogue Karibe. 28 x 35 cm.


Todos los patrocinadores recibirán un PDF con el libro de fotografías Post Dembow Tempo.

  • Por $10, recibirás mi agradecimiento personal e inclusión en el listado de patrocinadores.
  • Por $25, recibiras un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión en el listado de patrocinadores así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración
  • Por $50, recibirás una impresión de mi obra en tamaño postal 10 x 15 cm.  Un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión en el listado de patrocinadores así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración.    
  •  Por $100 recibirás 1 impresión de los estudios para Vogue Karibe, en tamaño 21,5 x 28 cm; un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión en el listado de patrocinadores así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración.
  • Por $250, recibirás un original de los estudios para Vogue Karibe, de 21,5 x 28 cm;  un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión en el listado de patrocinadores así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración.                                                                                                                                                     

 

Aya, 2016. Estudio, serie Vogue Karibe. 21,5 x 28 cm. / Aya, 2016. Sketch, series Vogue Karibe. 21.5 x 28 cm.


  • Por $450, recibirás una obra original de la serie Vogue Karibe, collage,  28 x 35,6 cm; un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión como patrocinador destacado, así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración.

Alek, 2016. Serie Vogue Karibe. 28x 35,6 cm. / Alek, 2016. Series Vogue Karibe. 28x 35.6 cm.


  • Por $450, recibirás una fotografía impresa en papel de archivo Hahnemühle Fine Art intervenida con cinta, de la serie Karakashi Kollection, 27 x 20 cm; un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión como patrocinador destacado, así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       

Sin título, 2016. Serie Karakashi Kollection. 27 x 20 cm. / Untitled, 2016. Series Karakashi Kollection. 27 x 20 cm.


  • Por $450, recibirás una fotografía impresa en papel de archivo Hahnemühle Fine Art intervenida con cinta, de la serie Karakashi Wall, 27 x 20 cm; un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión como patrocinador destacado, así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración.


Sin título, 2016. Serie Karakashi Wall. 27 x 20 cm. / Untitled, 2016. Series Karakashi Wall. 27 x 20 cm.


  • Por $450, recibirás una fotografía impresa en papel de archivo Hahnemühle Fine Art intervenida con cinta de la serie Zombies, 20 x 27 cm; un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión como patrocinador destacado, así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración.


Sin título, 2016. Serie Zombies. 20 x 27 cm. / Untitled, 2016. Series Karakashi Wall. 27 x 20 cm.


  • Por $550, una carpeta LP de la serie Post Dembow Tempo. Serie limitada a 21 copias por LP, objetos únicos intervenidos individualmente, 62,5 x 31 cm (abierto); un video mensaje de agradecimiento personal, inclusión como patrocinador destacado, así como una invitación por correo electrónico para la inauguración.                                                                                                                    

 Sin título, 2016. Portada/contraportada del LP #11, serie Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62,5 cm. / Untitled, 2016. Front and back cover of LP #11, series Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62.5 cm.

Sin título, 2016. Interior del LP #11, serie Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62,5 cm.  / Untitled, 2016. Inside cover of LP #11, series Post Dembow Tempo. 31 x 62.5 cm.


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

 Todas las aportaciones son bienvenidas. También puedes respaldar la campaña difundiéndola a través de las redes sociales entre tus amigos y conocidos.
Muchas gracias por tu interés y tu inestimable ayuda.
Héctor Eliazar Ortiz Roa

About Me

I’m Eliazar Ortiz, a Dominican multidisciplinary artist. I studied Civil Engineering at the UNPHU and started working in that field; however I ended up abandoning it to dedicate myself to art, my true vocation. I was trained as a photographer at the EAF in Buenos Aires, where my first works were shown. Returning to Santo Domingo in 2013, I participated and won Honorable Mention in the Biennial of Visual Arts.

 In 2015, I was awarded the Exposition Prize as part of the Youth Prize of Centro de la Imagen in Santo Domingo. This prize consists in the Centro providing gallery space and curatorial services but does not contribute towards production of the work itself, frames, transport, invitations, costs for the opening night event or for the performance.

The exhibition is scheduled to take place in the Centro de la Imagen in September 2016. It will be my first solo exhibition.

Post Dembow Tempo 

Giving form to a project based on photography has been a challenge, as this is one artistic discipline for which I feel especially passionate. I began this voyage as a search for an esthetic and conceptual identity, taking asreference point elements from photography and the cinema as well as cultural syncretism, very present in our day-to-day living in what for me is its most complex manifestation: the continuous construction of our own creole.

The exhibition consists of five photographic and video installations. On opening night there will be a happening with live music. We will be counting on the presence of a “palero” or Dominican percussion player, and collaborating with us from Brussels,   dø√∑ Ç@K∑::: will be providing electronic music. Elements worn by the performance artists (clothing-books-magazines-photographs) will subsequently become part of the installations.

In our time, things happen so quickly that more importance is given over to the disposable. The value of objects that have survived due to their personal stamp seduces me, and that’s why I’ve tried to rescue those icons of a bygone technology which opened up our senses and taught us to see the world and art in new ways. Vinyl LP’s, VHS tapes, cassettes, books and magazines: I take these and transform them into photographic and video installations, trying to recover the essence they conveyed to me, making them over into new items which are not what they seem.

Mix – that is the basis of Post Dembow Tempo: seeing how we deny one culture that dances with another, at the same time reaffirming a common past, where it is our job to rediscover them and tell new stories. Stores which I prefer to be not so much realistic as derived from the mixture that characterizes our island: a Dembow recomposed and deconstructed somewhere between the Absurd and the post-conceptual.

What We Need

In order to make this exhibition a reality we need $5, 300, to cover the costs of:

·  Photographic prints

·  Frames

·  Construction and metalwork for the installations

·  Wardrobe for the performance

·  Performance artists

·  Musicians

·  Catering at the opening event

·  Transportation of the works from my studio in Samana

·  Video documentation of the performance

The success of this project depends on our achieving the goal. Some items were excluded in order to avoid having too high a budget that would frustrate our expectations. However, we will be flexible with our goals and adapt our proposal to the final amount raised. Hopefully, your contributions will exceed the initial goal and allow us to realize this project as it was originally conceived.

What You Get

I do believe one can be an artist and make a living through self-management. Some of the items from the installations – photographs, collage, objects – will also become part of the recompense for your support. I hope you like them.

All our sponsors will receive a PDF of Post Dembow Tempo, a book of photographs.

Other Ways You Can Help

All your contributions are welcome. You can also help by sharing this campaign with friends and associates on your social network.

Many thanks for your interest and for your immeasurable help.

Hector Eliazar Ortiz Roa

All our sponsors will receive a PDF of Post Dembow Tempo, a book of
photographs.
Other Ways You Can Help
All your contributions are welcome. You can also help by sharing this
campaign with friends and associates on your social network.
Many thanks for your interest and for your immeasurable help.
Hector Eliazar
Ortiz Roa

story:
Rowandale's story.....

Thank your for getting this far! We are a family owned business that focuses on turning unused and unwanted items into functional art and furniture.  We love to revive items and make them useful and beautiful again!

We began in 2012 with just a few old pieces of barnwood from our farm and now we collect wood from all over!

By supporting our campaign you are helping not only our business to succeed but you are helping your community to make an impact on landfill waste.

We plan on having a communication spot on our website and our Facebook page where if you have old items that you want to dispose of that we might use you can message us! 

We are going to offer classes for everyone from pre-school and home-school classes to pain relief specific classes to help people suffering from debilitating chronic pain learn ways that they can still create!!

When you invest in us you are investing in a family owned local business that plans on being in town and contributing to the community for a very long time!

story:
My name is Heidi Wood and I am an artist in Bellingham, Washingon. I paint abstracts and landscapes mostly, using acrylic and oils  I started painting late in life and found such joy in it that I wanted to share the experience with others.

Finger painting seemed an ideal way to introduce non-painters to painting. We poured liquid paint on paper and watched it make beautiful shapes. Those who tried it were amazed with their creativity.  I was delighted at the effect it  had  on people. It seemed to put them in the "zone " and remove their stress. We need this so badly in our stressful world. It is so much fun. I want to get out in their community and share this experience with everyone.

FINGER PAINTING FOR GROWNUPS

As George Bernard Shaw said "We don't stop playing because we grow old, we grow old because we stop playing." We launched Finger Painting for Grownups in order to offer adults a rejuvenating experience: finger painting as we did as children, but with food, drink and socializing with other like minded adults.  There is something about the classes that feels almost magical.  The participants leave feeling lighthearted, energized and pleased with their hitherto unrealized creativity.

There is very little instruction, no rules and it's impossible to make a mistake. Participants are provided with high quality paint and paper and are encouraged to experiment with color and techniques. Each class starts with participants doing individual paintings and then progressing to doing a painting with one other person. The final painting is done by all the participants combined. Because of the teamwork involved, our classes are ideal as team building exercises at workplace conferences and staff retreats.

One of the ways we will use this money is to enable us to donate finger painting sessions for worthy causes, such as women's shelters  or transition houses.

We also a fun and original activity for events such as baby showers, bridal showers, birthdays, family reunions and anything else that groups of people get together to enjoy themselves.

Did I mention as well as the benefits, it is so much fun.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

We need most of funding to get word out there to get people in to our gallery to try finger painting. It is a difficult concept to explain, so you need to do it before you understand the effect it will have on you and how much fun you will have.

Budget. -We expect it will take a year to get off the ground. Our funding request is calculated for one year of expenses.

Marketing Person  20 hrs. a week.  @ 13.50   $13,500

Ads, promos and material                                     $3,800

Instructors                                                                  $9,000.

Supplies (Paint, Paper etc. )                                 $2,100

Partial Rent of Gallery for Classes.                     $6.800

 Internet Share (50 %per Year )                           $1,600

Total Request                                                       $  36,800

PERKS

$25.00 amount Thank You Star on the outside wall of Gallery Pegasus

$50,00  an original matted finger painting.

$100.00  T shirt with original finger painting printed on it.

$250.00 finger painting kit. Paints, paper, apron, gloves, instructional video

 

 

If we don't reach our goal, the money we get  will be spent on Marketing so that we can expose as many people to Finger Painting and perhaps create a few more artists.

The Impact

In our technological world we spend most of our time with our head  in our cell phones or glued to many other screens.  We take ourselves so seriously and work ourselves to death.

We have forgotten how to play. Finger  Painting is a wonderful form of play. There is no pressure to produce anything specific, no competition, no mistakes. It is just you with your fingers playing in paint.  Imagine enjoying a glass of wine, listening to music and  being your creative self.

This project is valuable to me because we are making a contribution to others' well being and that in itself is of value to the world.

 

 

Risks & Challenges*****

The main obstacle for this project is getting people convinced that it is acceptable to play and be silly and childlike.

I have post graduate degrees in Adult Education. I have trained teachers and done many years of corporate training.  People generally like me and trust that I have their welfare in mind.

I have lots of experience with motivating people. The instructors working with me all have masters degrees and they love to finger paint.

Other Ways You Can Help***

Yelp ,like pages, tell firends

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
