story:
Art LovHer is a collective of artists that uses a co-operative economics business model to create opportunities of empowerment & visibility for traditionally marginalized artists. We work to create and maintain safe spaces of artistic exchange where our respective communities intersect & grow from. 

 Through our monthly artist salons and various art events like The Annual FeMC Festival and gallery exhibitions,  Art LovHer creates a crossroads of life & art where we find our commonalities, and create connection.  

We've been given the opportunity to bring Art LovHer artists to California for performances this July!! Starting with Creative Assembly and House of Blues before heading up to the Bay area!


We're reaching out to our community for help to raise the $4000.00 we need for this to be successful!



What We Need & What You Get


Break it down for folks in more detail:

We need:

  • $1500 - Covers housing costs for the 5 billed artists. We took the average price from our  wishlist on air b&b. We did include $100 in estimated tax. 
  • $1040 - Covers transportation for the 11 days we will be touring in California. We plan on either renting an SUV from Budget or using our Zip Car Membership. Again, we took the average of the two prices to get what we would be spending on rental and gas for the 11 days we'll be in California. 
  • $275 - Covers food for all artists. We live how we work. This is will allow us to buy food and cook meals for the house while traveling. (none of those meals include alcohol, just FYI)
  • $500 GoPro Camera, carrying case  & mount to capture the our first outing out West. We'd like to document the trip and performances for future short film footage and fellowship/residency/grant applications. Many grants we apply for want to see what we do, this footage will take us a long way in getting lobg term support!  (feel free to gift us the camera via this link -> http://shop.gopro.com/cameras/heroplus-lcd/CHDHB-101.html )
  • $545 cushion for incidentals like the random flat tire or tow, extra tax, outside musician fee,  etc. It's always best to be prepared for what could happen. Just in case our estimates are too low we'd like to be ready.


Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

OH MY GOSH!!! The impact you will make by helping us spread these amazing artists across the country.

 Not to mention, your contribution allows us to  connect with LA Based non-profit Off The Wall Graffiti. Helping with their program while we're out there! 

By donating to Art LovHer's tour you are:

  • Giving independent artists the opportunity for self-created success. 
  • Helping to spread art and ideas that make an impact. 
  • Helping art to flourish in underserved communities.    
  • Supporting the expansion and necessity of safe spaces. 


In the last 4 years since Art LovHer's creation, we've had the opportunity to work with and connect hundreds of women, black, and LGBTQ artists. We are more than an event company, we are an experience. We create an atmosphere that has given numerous voices a sense of validation and security, unfound in day to day society. For that we are grateful, yet, curious. How many more people crave these spaces? Need these spaces? 

Being in NYC, I've met and worked with so many people from so many places. A common comment is that the environment of the musical/artistic communities are very different than hat we have here. SO I thought why not take Art LovHer to these places? 

I can't begin to describe how incredible it is to see an artist that I presented years ago, tell us how being a feature at an Art LovHer Salon literally launched her artist career. Or how it changed her parents support for her artistry. Or have someone  share his secret in room full of strangers. Sometimes, all people need to be their best and truest self is a little push in the form of a safe space that encourages them to be free. Perhaps Art LovHer is that loving nudge,  for artist and audience alike, to feel safe to share life with each other. We'll never know until we try..  

This is me trying. I have literally put everything I've had into Art LovHer for the last 4 years. At times forgoing the logical choices of others so that the community I want to strengthen can exist for those who need it. For those who are afraid of how powerful they can be. 

 People often ask me, why pay artists? Or why put myself in debt to help someone else become successful? I still have no answer for that. My best answer is that connecting people is what I know my life's purpose to be. I know that the world has an inherent need for beauty and art in the world. I know that I have done nothing, outside of motherhood, that feels this natural and necessary in this world. I hope you will support this vision. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just don't have it to give (we definitely understand), BUT that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • #sharingisfree - If you like something, you're going to tell someone right? So if you support what we are working to create, share it with your friends.If you like the artists we rock with, share this campaign!  You never know who else can help. So pass it on! It takes no time and costs no money.
  • #connectwithus - If you know people in the LA, San Diego, San Francisco or Oakland area that are involved in arts, help us connect. Send us your recommendations for open mics & jam sessions. Let us know if you know someone subletting, maybe we can save on lodging.. Any help &/or tips are appreciated.
  • #supporttheartist - Buy our merch! Whether it's an album, event,  book, t-shirt or whatever, buy the things we create so we don't have to do fundraisers..  :D  (A good place to start is the Art LovHer Volume 1 mixtape, currently available for digital download.)

And that's all there is to it.


Thanks so much for reading!

<3 & Art,

Joi Sanchez, Founder Art LovHer LLC
story_txt:
Art LovHer is a collective of artists that uses a co-operative economics business model to create opportunities of empowerment & visibility for traditionally marginalized artists. We work to create and maintain safe spaces of artistic exchange where our respective communities intersect & grow from. 
 Through our monthly artist salons and various art events like The Annual FeMC Festival and gallery exhibitions,  Art LovHer creates a crossroads of life & art where we find our commonalities, and create connection.  
We've been given the opportunity to bring Art LovHer artists to California for performances this July!! Starting with Creative Assembly and House of Blues before heading up to the Bay area!

We're reaching out to our community for help to raise the $4000.00 we need for this to be successful!


What We Need & What You Get
 
Break it down for folks in more detail:
We need:  $1500 - Covers housing costs for the 5 billed artists. We took the average price from our  wishlist on air b&b. We did include $100 in estimated tax. 
$1040 - Covers transportation for the 11 days we will be touring in California. We plan on either renting an SUV from Budget or using our Zip Car Membership. Again, we took the average of the two prices to get what we would be spending on rental and gas for the 11 days we'll be in California. 
$275 - Covers food for all artists. We live how we work. This is will allow us to buy food and cook meals for the house while traveling. (none of those meals include alcohol, just FYI)
$500 GoPro Camera, carrying case  & mount to capture the our first outing out West. We'd like to document the trip and performances for future short film footage and fellowship/residency/grant applications. Many grants we apply for want to see what we do, this footage will take us a long way in getting lobg term support!  (feel free to gift us the camera via this link -> http://shop.gopro.com/cameras/heroplus-lcd/CHDHB-101.html )
$545 cushion for incidentals like the random flat tire or tow, extra tax, outside musician fee,  etc. It's always best to be prepared for what could happen. Just in case our estimates are too low we'd like to be ready.

 
Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:
OH MY GOSH!!! The impact you will make by helping us spread these amazing artists across the country.
 Not to mention, your contribution allows us to  connect with LA Based non-profit Off The Wall Graffiti. Helping with their program while we're out there! 
By donating to Art LovHer's tour you are:  Giving independent artists the opportunity for self-created success. 
Helping to spread art and ideas that make an impact.  Helping art to flourish in underserved communities.    
Supporting the expansion and necessity of safe spaces. 



In the last 4 years since Art LovHer's creation, we've had the opportunity to work with and connect hundreds of women, black, and LGBTQ artists. We are more than an event company, we are an experience. We create an atmosphere that has given numerous voices a sense of validation and security, unfound in day to day society. For that we are grateful, yet, curious. How many more people crave these spaces? Need these spaces? 
Being in NYC, I've met and worked with so many people from so many places. A common comment is that the environment of the musical/artistic communities are very different than hat we have here. SO I thought why not take Art LovHer to these places? 
I can't begin to describe how incredible it is to see an artist that I presented years ago, tell us how being a feature at an Art LovHer Salon literally launched her artist career. Or how it changed her parents support for her artistry. Or have someone  share his secret in room full of strangers. Sometimes, all people need to be their best and truest self is a little push in the form of a safe space that encourages them to be free. Perhaps Art LovHer is that loving nudge,  for artist and audience alike, to feel safe to share life with each other. We'll never know until we try..  
This is me trying. I have literally put everything I've had into Art LovHer for the last 4 years. At times forgoing the logical choices of others so that the community I want to strengthen can exist for those who need it. For those who are afraid of how powerful they can be. 
 People often ask me, why pay artists? Or why put myself in debt to help someone else become successful? I still have no answer for that. My best answer is that connecting people is what I know my life's purpose to be. I know that the world has an inherent need for beauty and art in the world. I know that I have done nothing, outside of motherhood, that feels this natural and necessary in this world. I hope you will support this vision.    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just don't have it to give (we definitely understand), BUT that doesn't mean they can't help:  #sharingisfree - If you like something, you're going to tell someone right? So if you support what we are working to create, share it with your friends.If you like the artists we rock with, share this campaign!  You never know who else can help. So pass it on! It takes no time and costs no money.
#connectwithus - If you know people in the LA, San Diego, San Francisco or Oakland area that are involved in arts, help us connect. Send us your recommendations for open mics & jam sessions. Let us know if you know someone subletting, maybe we can save on lodging.. Any help &/or tips are appreciated.
#supporttheartist - Buy our merch! Whether it's an album, event,  book, t-shirt or whatever, buy the things we create so we don't have to do fundraisers..  :D  (A good place to start is the Art LovHer Volume 1 mixtape, currently available for digital download.)   And that's all there is to it.Thanks so much for reading!<3 & Art,Joi Sanchez, Founder Art LovHer LLC

story:
♥ Summary ♥

  • My name is Fabienne Giselle Delacroix, and I am an Afro-Brasilian and Creole  multimedia artist, burlesque dancer, community organizer,stripper,and healer from New Orleans who has been creating and working in the Bay Area for the past 5 years. I started my organization Cult of Gira (Gorgeously Illuminated Radical Adepts) a year ago during a transformative period in my life in which I discovered that I wanted to heal and inspire others through my art for the rest of my life, and facilitate a space for others in my community to do so as well. I also was inspired to share my spirituality and the revelations I have received through the evolutionary powers of the the Quimbanda goddess Pomba Gira. It has been my dream to combine arts, philanthropy, healing, and community organizing into a non-profit organization through which I can work with my community.

  • This campaign is important to me and my community of women of color creators because as marginalized people in society, we are often barred from expressing ourselves to the fullest extent of our capabilities because of who we are and how we present ourselves. Cult of Gira has facilitated a space for our fullest potentials to blossom in conjunction with our shared interests, gifts, and desires to empower our community locally, nationwide, and beyond.

  • What you would contribute to by helping us achieve our goals is non-profit status through which we will be able to have the means to provide free health and wellness workshops, retreats, co-operative events where we share food and resources, as well as art shows that increase the visibility or Afro-Caribbean spirituality in the United States,  and that fundraise for organizations that aid victims of sexual violence and persecution. 

♥ The Exchange ♥

  • We are asking for only the tip of the iceberg with a figure of 4444 to cover the following:
    -fees to register our business as a certified non-profit organization
    -business materials and electronics to help us connect with our communities
    -the funds able to gather the resources to create and erect the first life-size monument to Pomba Gira in in the United States
    -the deposit to put on a space from which we can work from; Culthouse Studios.
  • Our perks include commissioned, unique, one of a kind pieces of visual and performance art from the sought after creator of the organization, which also double as magickal items for which you can set your own positive intentions with, items that aid in your professional and spiritual development, and personal one-on-one entertainment experiences that are sure to last a lifetime. 
  • If we don't reach the entirety of our goal, we will put the gathered funds to achieving non-profit status as this is the key ingredient to our capabilities expanding. 

♥ The Contribution ♥

  • In a constantly shifting world, the only thing that stands firm is the healing and restorative powers that lie within the realm of the Divine Feminine, as her contribution and gift of birthing new life into this world is the key to progression of life on this earth. The charmed powers that rise to divine revelation when groups of creatrixes get together inspire others to release their pain and move stagnant energies that are impacting them as a result of intergenerational trauma, ostracizing and persecution.  Cult of Gira is an oasis where this energy can build and flourish; a living testament to the power of transformation. This community will give rise to evolution of trauma in an artful, spiritual and sophisticated way. Your contribution will ensure the protection of this movement.

♥ The Challenges ♥
 

In order to remain empowered and genuine when doing this work, it is important for safe haven to be constructed and offered without the pressure of reaching financial goals. As a leader, I know that this is not possible when I do not have that safety myself. In order to continue to have this movement come completely from Spirit alone, I am reaching out to my community for support in obtaining the legal security and registrations necessary to protect our movement and those who choose to be involved in it. I choose to work with women of color, I choose to stand up for marginalized people and sex workers, and you can now make the choice to stand with me.

♥ Other Ways You Can Participate ♥

  • In understanding the flux of circumstance and resources, we would like to invite you to participate in as many ways as possible, outside of donating. 
     *✦* LIKE the Cult of Gira Facebook page!
    *✦* FOLLOW the Cult of Gira Instagram page!
    *✦* VISIT http://www.cultofgira.org
    *✦* VISIT http://www.777DELACROIX777.com   
    *✦* SHARE this Campaign with your community on FACEBOOK, TWITTER, TUMBLR, or INSTAGRAM

story:
THE WASTELANDS PROJECT

ABANDON ALL DESPAIR, YE WHO ENTER HERE.

The Silent Revolution

Western Civilization is self-destructing all around us, and it’s never looked so under control. Wolf hunts, receding glaciers, the dream of a gardened planet: the ecological crisis spreads across the plains like an endless chain of luxury high rises. We believe there is a light to be found in the dark rows ahead. But to see it, we first need to stretch our imagination.

That's where we enter the Wastelands, an outdoor, traveling live performance about the future of life on Earth.


The Wastelands

The Wastelands is a revolutionary art project, loosely based on Dante's Purgatorio,  that transcends medium--theatre, music, film, dance, fine art, adventurous travel--from us, an emerging ensemble called Children of the Wild.

 From April 20th-May 18th, 2015 we will travel across the Great Lakes in search of people to engage with and locations to bring The Wastelands. Ultimately we aim to uncover the real-life stories of environmental crimes suffered by the Great Lakes Basin. More importantly we seek out the resistance of communities that won't back down until the Lakes are free. Why the Great Lakes? We are living in a watershed moment, so it helps to look at our watershed.

WHO ARE WE? Children of the Wild, an ensemble of North American artists, currently in residence at Double Edge Theatre in Ashfield, MA.

Our mission is to make original works of theatre and film that further the rewilding of the human spirit as part of a common struggle for social and environmental justice.

Rewilding Theatre

Over the next two years, we are building our show out of and performing in the detritus of this world—ruins of factories, overgrown lots, junk piles that were once industrial parks. We envision being costumed by dust and dirt, ash and burlap; we imagine a set made from found objects; we will travel in an adventurous way (bus or boat) and live as a tribe, in order to open space for what is possible politically and culturally. The film will faithfully document our tour, exposing the in-between places where fiction meets reality.

But why go through all that trouble just to tell a story? We believe in order talk about rewilding our souls as well as our environments, we must live it. So the question is, Where do we look to find a landbase reinventing itself in order to survive an almost certain death?


The Commons

We look inside. In the summer and fall of 2016 we will travel with this performance across the Great Lakes—the Inner Coast of North America—to share our stories with communities fighting to establish the Great Lakes Commons. This struggle is the real-life battle for the soul of the Basin.

Our OUTREACH & ENGAGEMENT TOUR will chart the terrain for our Performance Tour of 2016, passing though big cities, rural towns, and wilderness areas, laying bare where and how places are tending toward the wild. This project is art that is actively engaged in political struggles, but not activist art. Your support of our travels - by way of a donation or spreading the word - is essential for getting us there.


What We Need

The task ahead is clear: we need the gas and vehicle costs to travel the 1,500 miles from Ashfield, MA, along the southern border of the Great Lakes to Minneapolis, MN and back; we need STAGE LIGHTS to illuminate our show, which will be performed outside at night; we need a DIGITAL FILM PROJECTOR to share our work with potential collaborators and community members; we need FOOD AND SHELTER and we need to provide ourselves an EMERGENCY FUND, because if we don't plan for an accident, it will happen.

We are in need of a new story, and the movement toward rewilding the commons provides a powerful one: making safe space to voice our common problems and poetically chart our common ground. With your help we can add necessary artistic momentum to this movement.

The Wild

But really, who is Children of the Wild?

------------------------                www.childrenofthewild.org               -----------------------------

Children of the Wild began as The Unseen Ghost Brigade, a Minnesota-based ensemble that formed in 2009 with a mission to provide free theatrical and cinematic experiences to communities along the Mississippi River, to document marginalized ways of life along the River, to explore the historical impacts of industry along the River, and to further theater and cinema as direct actions of social life.

In 2010, the UGB created a live comedy about the deaths of historical vagabonds and toured it down the Mississippi on a raft they built themselves. They performed for free in parks and empty lots, on street corners and riverbanks, and survived by and large on what they earned by passing a hat after their shows. In six months they made it 1,000 miles from Minneapolis, MN to Caruthersville, MO, a cultural oxbow just north of Memphis, TN. The seven hundred hours of footage captured on the journey became the feature-length, award-winning documentary Twilight of the Mississippi.

In 2012, Double Edge Theatre offered Walken of the UGB a mentorship in the development of his next project, which he pursued with fellow UGB member Augustin as part of a new ensemble, Children of the Wild. Double Edge Theatre resides in the foothills of the Berkshires where they operate a farm and foster a rich environment for both experiential learning and performance. Under their wing, COW has been developing, you guessed it, The Wastelands Project.

The Wastelands Project is about the places that bridge life and death, love and rage, hope and despair. It is about resistance; it is about the queerness in our souls, it is about everything we can hardly dare to dream could be possible, but need to. The barren starkness of the Wastelands is already spreading like wildfire, but that is exactly why Children of the Wild is making this performance: because the forest has not yet burned to the ground.

This project will be simple, but not easy. So what are we up against?

The Garden

Italian author Italian Calvino may best sum up the stakes and soul of this project in the last words of his masterpiece Invisible Cities:

"The inferno of the living is not something that will be; if there is one, it is something that is already here, the inferno where we live every day, that we form by being together. There are two ways to escape suffering it. The first is easy for many: accept the inferno and become such a part of it that you can no longer see it. The second is risky and demands constant vigilance and apprehension: seek and learn to recognize who and what, in the midst of inferno, are not inferno, then make them endure, give them space."

The wild is coming up. We just have to see it.

You can help give it space. Join the momentum at childrenofthewild.org

story:
Short Summary

The aims of the voluntary organization known as "Minturno in movimento" are:

- to foster and promote initiatives and forms of direct democracy in order to give the citizens the possibility of intervening about decisions made by the representatives elected in the institutions;

- to promote and to coordinate initiatives and activities intended to preserve the territory, the environment, animals and the historical, artistic, cultural and folkloristic heritage in general.

Cristoforo Sparagna was an Artist lived in Minturno, he had given to the municipality of the Town his house in order to destinate it to Cultural and social activities. We wish to pursue this aim of the Poet and see his dream comes true.

We offer to the contributors, in particular to migrant's descendants, the opportunity to visit and to discover the land of their roots.

See the video also in italian language:


See the video also in spanish language:

story:
Mission

This project is for helping my friend, Kestutis Ptakauskas, to fund his annual event – “European bonsai and suiseki convention and 4th Japanese culture festival”

Who is Domas?

I am an engineer, on my spare time I do voluntary job. I help to my friends and organizations I belong to organize activities. I started at youth organization “Business angel” on 2004, and try to do good till now.

Why is it important?

Kestutis is organizing events to promote Japanese arts and culture in Lithuania since 2004. I saw how hard it is to collect enough funds for him. This year we have discussed a lot about the need to organize an event, when support is so moderate. At first there were a lot of government officials, who said: “Just bring an event of such scale and of such international importance and you get your funds from city municipality and national culture funds”. But at the end, it all is just a promise.

Worst case scenario

Because of insufficient funds, this event will put my friend, who is personally responsible, in huge debt, and we have no more such events in Lithuania ever, where we can touch traditional Japanese culture. This event will be high quality anyway, but it might be the last one. So I decided to help with all my knowledge that this would never happen.

How much we need?

Event’s budget is about 143 100 euro. It consists of:

Venue and exhibition equipment’s rent: 29 000 euro

Administrative costs: 4 200 euro

Expenses for performers, masters, dancers and singers’ meal’s, accommodation and transportation (130 person form Japan and other countries, 5 nights): 93 300 euro

Publicity, advertising, banners, posters and etc.: 16 600 euro

Already gathered from various sponsors: 22 000 euro

Expecting from event tickets: 15 000 euro

In total, at a given day, we are 106 100 euro short.

How much from indiegogo community?

Well, it would be totally great to gather all 100 000 euro (approx 109 000 dollars), to cover the rest of expenses through indiegogo.com, but we will set our goal to $ 30 000 to see what happens. I hope those who value Japanese culture will make a miracle.

Perks?

Check out perks on your right. As an overall perk we are planting one Sakura tree for every thousand dollars gathered at "Vilnius Japanese garden" (for more information about "Vilnius Japanese garden" project visit http://www.vilniausjaponiskassodas.lt). The area where Sakura's grows will be named by the platform it was funded through - "Indiegogo community sakura garden". We will put plate with the name and message - "Sakura's planting was funded through indiegogo platform, by awesome people".

You can help

Spread the word about this campaign, share at your Facebook wall, make it visible. If you have any questions or other ideas, that can help, contact us by e-mail: fund.japanfest2015@gmail.com

Previous events

You can see pictures from previous events at the gallery of the campaign, at the Kestutis Ptakauskas personal Facebook page and Picasa gallery (links added below).

Also you can see videos at my YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/5235887/videos

Contact us:

fund.japanfest2015@gmail.com

Additional links:

Official event webpage: http://www.japanfest2015.lt/

Event Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Japonijos-men%C5%B3-festivalis/208419209186394?sk=timeline

Full gallery of Kestutis Ptakauskas activities till 2012: http://picasaweb.google.com/bonsailithuania

For photo and video - www.dariustudio.lt
story_txt:
Mission
This project is for helping my friend, Kestutis Ptakauskas,
to fund his annual event – “European bonsai and suiseki convention and 4th
Japanese culture festival”
Who is Domas?
I am an engineer, on my spare time I do voluntary job. I
help to my friends and organizations I belong to organize activities. I started
at youth organization “Business angel” on 2004, and try to do good till now. 
Why is it important?
Kestutis is organizing events to promote Japanese arts and
culture in Lithuania since 2004. I saw how hard it is to collect enough funds
for him. This year we have discussed a lot about the need to organize an event,
when support is so moderate. At first there were a lot of government officials,
who said: “Just bring an event of such scale and of such international
importance and you get your funds from city municipality and national culture funds”.
But at the end, it all is just a promise.
Worst case scenario
Because of insufficient funds, this event will put my
friend, who is personally responsible, in huge debt, and we have no more such
events in Lithuania ever, where we can touch traditional Japanese culture. This
event will be high quality anyway, but it might be the last one. So I decided
to help with all my knowledge that this would never happen.
How much we need?
Event’s budget is about 143 100 euro. It consists of:
Venue and exhibition equipment’s rent: 29 000 euro
Administrative costs: 4 200 euro
Expenses for performers, masters, dancers and singers’
meal’s, accommodation and transportation (130 person form Japan and other
countries, 5 nights): 93 300 euro
Publicity, advertising, banners, posters and etc.: 16 600
euro
Already gathered from various sponsors: 22 000 euro
Expecting from event tickets: 15 000 euro
In total, at a given day, we are 106 100 euro short.
How much from indiegogo community?
Well, it would be totally great to
gather all 100 000 euro (approx 109 000 dollars), to cover the rest of expenses through indiegogo.com, but we
will set our goal to $ 30 000 to see what happens. I hope those who value
Japanese culture will make a miracle.
Perks?
Check out perks on your right. As an overall perk we are
planting one Sakura tree for every thousand dollars gathered at "Vilnius
Japanese garden" (for more information about "Vilnius Japanese
garden" project visit http://www.vilniausjaponiskassodas.lt). The area where
Sakura's grows will be named by the platform it was funded through -
"Indiegogo community sakura garden". We will put plate with the name
and message - "Sakura's planting was funded through indiegogo platform, by
awesome people".You can helpSpread the word about this campaign, share at your Facebook wall, make it visible. If you have any questions or other ideas, that can help, contact us by e-mail: fund.japanfest2015@gmail.comPrevious events

You can see pictures
from previous events at the gallery of the campaign, at the Kestutis Ptakauskas
personal Facebook page and Picasa gallery (links added below).
Also you can see
videos at my YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/5235887/videos
Contact us:
fund.japanfest2015@gmail.com
Additional links:
Official event webpage: http://www.japanfest2015.lt/
Event Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Japonijos-men%C5%B3-festivalis/208419209186394?sk=timeline
Kestutis Ptakauskas personal Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/rytietis
Full gallery of Kestutis Ptakauskas activities till 2012: http://picasaweb.google.com/bonsailithuania
“Bonsai studio” - nonprofit public institution webpage: www.bonsai.lt
“Vilnius Japanese garden” webpage: http://www.vilniausjaponiskassodas.lt/
“Vilnius Japanese garden” Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/VilniausJaponiskasSodas

Special thanks
For photo and video - www.dariustudio.lt

story:
We are Ted and Kate Jauw. Surcadiana. We also are teachers, artists, musicians and storytellers. We believe in doing 'Art For A Cause' because we are also parents, children, friends and human beings who love Freedom. For everyone.

The Blue Bead Project is about people. It’s about awareness. It’s about making a difference. We want millions of people to 'Wear The Bead'. A symbol that says you are speaking out and doing something about modern slavery in all its forms. Wearing a Blue Bead is one thing that everyone can do.

Our goal is to get 21 million beads on twenty one million people. That’s one bead for every person trapped in slavery today. Just as when Harriet Tubman walked the earth, slavery is Real. Here. Now.

We are starting a new railroad. But it won’t be underground this time.

Our portion of this project is to create an installation for ArtPrize 7, the largest Art 'competition' in the World. And while the eyes of the World are on This Place, This Venue and This Space, we will offer this art, this altar and over 21,000,000 beads as a symbol for a prayer, a wish, a hope and a dream; a symbol for Freedom. 

Help us take our art and our message to the world. Tell us why you will wear the Bead. Take a picture. Make a movie. Start a movement.

Wear the Bead. We can make a difference, one person, one step, one bead at a time.



This campaign will help to create this art piece to bring awareness to modern day slavery, to put a face on this dehumanizing practice, to expose the depth to which this affects everyone on a Worldwide scale. Mostly, it will give all of us a way to express our awareness and wish to create solutions. 

Your support means that we, as a society, are choosing to no longer look the other way. We will start by speaking out as individuals,by wearing a single bead; but together, our voices will be so loud so as not to be ignored. That is when real change, real healing can begin. 



Why 'Wear the Blue Bead'?

The Blue Glass Dutch Trade Bead was commonly used as currency to buy and sell slaves between the 16th and 20th Century. It is a symbol of a period of time that we had hoped was over but it is not. There are more people enslaved today than during the Middle Passage. Our goal is to amass 21 million individual beads as part of the installation. 21 million is the estimated number of people enslaved in one form or another today. Each bead represents each person, woman and child who continue to suffer.

 

                   The Blue Bead Band                                    Grandma Moses Bracelet


Our first objective and first level is $2,000. That will go towards materials and the beads themselves. We intend to use ethically made and traded materials along the way and will also do that with our premiums.

If we go over that goal, we will be able to add more to our piece and pay other artisans to help us create it. For instance, we would love to have a real lantern made by a stained glass artist or create 'life molds' to make the figures come to life and seem to be alive and leaving the stained glass painting.

What is 'Wearing The Bead'?- 

We would love to reach our first goal by getting as many small donors as possibles. We want to reach people. To reach it, we are offering unique items, each including the blue bead in some form. We hope that you will wear them to remind yourself and others of those who still struggle. To remind yourself and others to make choices in your purchasing habits that support only free trade and not slave labor. Wear one to remind yourself to speak out when you see an injustice or to help our modern day abolitionists continue their work, until each and everyone of us is truly free. 

                                              The Choker (Chakra) of Truth


You can choose a simple bead on a card to carry with you, a bracelet, a choker, a waistbelt, even the crown of Yemaya. All to symbolize your commitment, your awareness and your desire for a better world. 


Not everyone wears jewelry so we have designed a temp tattoo that can be worn on your skin. Once we reach the first level we will add it to every other premium.

We also have many amazing artists who are designing the ritual adornments, waistbelts, pendants and crown that are shown on the actual art piece. They will be offering these pieces exclusively to help us.

What we really want are people to get these basic premiums because we want as many people to 'wear the bead' as possible. If you want to know why we care so much, please read on...


Why it Matters:

There are many reasons that people do art. For us, it's personal. For instance, slavery is not a 'passage' in history for me or my family. Good guys and bad. I was raised by slaves. Real slaves. Slavery so horrific that many in my family still cannot talk about it. Some will freely tell you about the horrors of the Japanese Concentration camps or Dutch Repatriation camps. But not their slavery.

My GrandMother was sold at birth, along with a dowry of priceless aluminum to a Mandarin "Captijn de Chinese" when she was a baby. Her own father bought 'second daughters' to trade and cement alliances with. My own father was raised by a slave named Poongoo, a black Melanesian woman who raised him, long after she was given her freedom during the revolution.

Art is complex. What we are creating is not a soundbite or a slogan. It is not a glimpse of the past or a re-imagining of the future. This is not just a picture but a call to action, a pledge to speak out, a provocation and a promise. From All of us.

Today (this very day) there are over twenty-one million slaves. Way more in the last three years than the three hundred year period we call Middle Passage and worse than at any other time in our history. Worse in every way; metric, age, torture, rape, genocide and worse in scope and intensity. The vast majority are women and children and no country is immune. Slavery isn't over or past and we are 'post' nothing when it comes to devaluing human life.

In the 1700's a slave might cost (worldwide) about six hundred dollars. That's about $43,000 US today. Today, the average slave costs about $90.00 US. They are virtually disposable and they are used and used up that way. It is a genocide.

My grandmother's priceless dowry of aluminum became worth nothing overnight when technology was able to extract it from rock. A miracle. What kind of miracle would it take to end modern slavery? What will it take to stop people from buying people? We won't know until we all are aware and can focus our collective strength, influence, power and, mostly, creativity on this horrible crime that is practically invisible.

We would like to make it visible and offer a first step...  we are FOR Freedom. We dont think there is any one answer and we believe as Harriet Tubman did that, 

"Every great dream begins with a dreamer. Always remember, you have within you the strength, the patience, and the passion to reach for the stars to change the world."

This is our dream...

Offer up a single bead, a seed. Wear it on your wrist or neck. Tell your story. This will only end when Empathy replaces Sympathy and Apathy. Wear a bead to remind yourself where your cheap goods come from. Wear a bead to remind yourself that this happens to children from every nation, race, religion or color. Wear a bead so people will ask you why... Then tell them your story.

Wear a bead...

Challenges: 

The biggest challenge we will face with this project is pulling together all the materials needed for the build, and getting the word out to the public. The art is important to us but it's potential impact is of more value. This is where you can help. Help us make some noise, help us speak out and speak up against slavery. Check our website for lists of groups that are on the forefront of this mission, contribute to them. Find out if what you are purchasing is made by slave labor, boycott those companies that use it.  Use the hashtag #TheBlueBeadProject, wear your bead proudly. Join us on our Facebook page for updates. Get involved. Use the Indiegogo "share" tools to help us spread the word.  One voice may not seem like much, but together, we will be heard. You can make a difference.

story:
I am an artist, a mother, a writer and many other things throughout the day. I have been invited to be part of a 3 week artist residency that, to me, is something of the stuff dreams are made. I live in Portland, OR with my husband and our 2 sons - aged 5 and nearly 7. In order to make this work, I need to raise some funds to help pay for the residency and buy airfare as well as to help ensure that my sons have the best care possible while I am gone.


The School of Making Thinking is located in the Catskills on a 10-acre farm in upstate New York. Here is a bit of a synopsis from their website:

“The School of Making Thinking (SMT) is simultaneously an artist/thinker residency program, an experimental college, and a nomadic investigation in intentional living. Our mission is to create a unique environment where participants are able to develop a creative practice that challenges disciplinary conventions of art-making, thinking and living. ”

This trip is important to me. As a parent and an artist, residencies pose a difficult question for me. Going means leaving my family, and though I know they and I will both be fine it is hard to make the choice to go. I have not been apart from them this long, ever. As an artist and creative person, I need to do this for my career, for my work and my personal growth and development. The contributions given here will help me support my family while gone and will help me afford the costs of travel and the costs of the residency. I appreciate every dollar given and will consider that as I work my way through the residency.


Needs & Gets

Residency costs: $600

Travel costs: approximately $600

Childcare assistance: $600

Supplies: $350

The perks (as they call them) are over there. YOU KNOW. OVER THERE.


Update:

I made this video with me talking about the residency.



Also - amazing news - A pal, Nancy Alexander, donated air miles to me and now I have tickets to and fro New York. My many thanks to her and to those who have donated. I greatly appreciate it!

story:
The American Veterans Building

Hoquiam, Washington U.S.A.

To better serve the community an effort has been initiated to purchase and renovate The American Veterans Building in Hoquiam, Washington. Over the period of the next 9 years a grand total of $999,999.99 will be sought for the Acquisition, Renovation and Community Programming of the building.

In the initial fund-raising phase $333,333.33 is sought for the purchase and the renovation of the Ballroom situated on the top floor to accomodate community events.

Built in 1920, shortly after World War I the building was a collaborative effort of the architects Roy Dobell and the Beezer Brothers.

The American Veterans Building is unique, as it is regarded to be the first building of its kind built in memoriam of and in service to United States Veterans; open for their use 24 hours a day until its closure in the 1970’s

Its history reveals that the building itself was the product of an early “crowd-funding” effort, financed through the contributions of individuals. The structure was purposely built as a mixed-use building, initially housing Lumberman’s Bank on the ground floor to provide a tenant income stream.

The building has been included on The National Register of Historic Places as of 2011.

story:
Inspired by the wonder of childhood carnival rides, Dreamland is an immersive and interactive environment that encapsulates the energy of this year's Burning Man theme, the Carnival of Mirrors. A whimsical experience of vivid colors, dazzling light and flame transport participants to the world of spectacle and the carnivalesque.

You can still donate!

Since we didn't reach our Indiegogo goal, FLUX still needs to raise about $10,000! You can still donate to help make magic! 
Go to: www.fluxfoundation.org/donate
Dreamland may have been created for Burning Man, but the vision of the Flux Foundation goes far beyond that of any event. What defines us is our devotion to creating art and community. We are a place where anyone, no matter how skilled, can walk in, join a project, and create art. We are constantly teaching and mentoring new artists and all we ask in return is that they create with us and give us their wholehearted participation while they’re in the shop. 
Your donations not only help to make the Dreamland installation possible, but they help to make the Flux Foundation itself financially sustainable and secure. Your support helps us keep the lights and helps us do what we love, and that means everything to us. 

Who we are

FLUX is a volunteer-based non-profit located in West Oakland, CA, at American Steel Studios, the largest industrial arts space on the West Coast. We've been building art together since 2010.

Our mission is to engage people in the designing and building of public art as a catalyst for education, collaboration and empowerment. We believe that every step in the art-making process is an opportunity to share ideas, knowledge and skills, and to create something monumental. 

Dreamland is our 14th sculpture together in five years. FLUX has an amazing track record of delivering incredible interactive sculptures. We've worked with diverse audiences around the country. In 2015, alone, we've created: 

  • Bloom! at the Philadelphia Zoo
  • Lacuna for the Bay Area Book Festival in Berkeley, CA

Check our our portfolio to see all our works.  


What is Dreamland? 

Undulating light and carnivalesque music spill across the desert night, beckoning participants to investigate. Bursts of flame punctuate the prismatic glow, seemingly random in duration and intensity. Upon approach, it becomes evident that the light, flame and music are connected parts of a singular attraction.

Dreamland is an immersive environment with a kinetic sculpture at its center. It’s an unexpected oasis that disappears and reappears on the horizon, far away from the city streets in deep playa. Its perimeter is delineated by lampposts, kaleidoscopes and large, comfortable benches that provide a space to relax and enjoy an atmosphere of revelry. 
As participants interact with the sculpture, they discover that they control the movement of the piece by turning a circular, central railing, which moves the arms above head, imitating the mechanics of a swing carousel. During the day, spinning the sculpture creates shifting patterns of shade and light as the sun filters through a fabric canopy.  A soundscape that echoes the boardwalk and bygone carnivals fades in and out. At night, the atmosphere becomes electrified. As the spinning arms reach different velocities, the piece comes alive with fire and light. 

Dreamland is a collaboration

Dreamland is the result of a collaboration among over 40 different people contributing to engineering, design, wood, metal, fabric, flame effects, lighting, technology, logistics, project management, fundraising, marketing, crew care and a number of surprise elements yet to be revealed. FLUX's process is radically-collaborative, allowing for each person’s artistic input to become an integral and valued part of the whole while maintaining the artistic integrity of the artwork.

Visual design partner

We are also collaborating on the design elements of Dreamland with our dear friend and remarkable sculpture artist, Kate Raudenbush. Based in New York, Kate focuses on large-scale allegorical environments are created as an experiential set-piece for elevated human connection and social dialogue. We are thrilled to be working with her to bring this piece to life.

Sound design partners

A core element of the Dreamland experience is the soundscape that will draw participants in and envelop them in the space. Sounds of the carnival, the boardwalk and the sea coupled with ethereal music will be the soundtrack of the piece. We're partnering with a handful of incredibly talented, renowned DJs and sound designers who are each creating a unique track for the piece. Our collaborators include: Flavio Lemelle, Simon Shackelton, Sleight of Hands, Myagi, Shengi, and Jem Stone, among others. 

Funding partners

Dreamland started its life as Carousel, a project funded by the Abundance Foundation for the Project Zero Perspectives: Making, Thinking, and Understanding educator's conference at Lick Wilmerding High School in San Francisco in October 2014. FLUX was thrilled to partner with Abundance and Project Zero to create an interactive experience at the conference that engaged educators from across the country who are committed to design thinking and making in school curriculum. 
Carousel evolved to Dreamland as a project for the 2015 Burning Man event. Burning Man has provided a generous grant for this project to support the enhanced interactivity and placemaking experience that Dreamland has become. 


Technology + Art = Magic

Dreamland is FLUX's most technical sculpture to date. While our previous pieces have included computer-controlled flame and lighting effects, with Dreamland we’re taking technology to a new level with a new capability in our teaching and art-making skillset.

Dreamland integrates large-scale fire art, LEDs, and sound into a unique experience that is both interactive and immersive. These effects are achieved by a central computer and a distributed network of Raspberry Pis, FadeCandy pixel drivers, velocity sensors, and other electrical components that run throughout the carousel, benches, and lampposts. Utilization of this data, along with novel programming techniques, allows the central computer to translate the actions of participants into sounds, lights, and fire effects. 


What happens to Dreamland after its debut? 

The great part about Dreamland is that it is made to scale to different environments and different audiences. We envision it creating an ethereal, interactive, and magical experience for a small town or large city.
Dreamland inherently creates a communal gathering point, and its unique spectacle allows for social barriers to be lowered and new friends made. The sculpture is meant to be in any place where people gather, such as a park or a public plaza. It could even be in a hotel lobby or a school. It's a playful sculpture that can be easily modified for any application. The effects could also be adjusted seasonally, or for special occasions.

 

What we need

We have received a generous grant from Burning Man for this project. We are looking to raise an additional $18,500 through this online campaign. Here's where your money will go: 

By supporting this art piece, you're supporting FLUX as a nonprofit committed to teaching people diverse art-making skills and transforming them into public artists. FLUX is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. As such, contributions made to this campaign for which you do not receive a gift are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. 

You're also supporting the future of Dreamland in another location, such as a public park or plaza in a city like Reno, NV, Philadelphia, PA, or Oakland, CA. 

FLUX is a reliable, dependable organization who delivers on its promises and creates remarkable experiences for makers and participants alike with its sculptures. You can count on your money making a difference. 


What you get

This is an opportunity to contribute to something very unique and special. At FLUX, we empower our volunteers to become artists, not because we have a grandiose idea of what that means, but because we believe that the ability to create art is an intrinsic part of what it means to be human. Dreamland is our lovesong to the union of childhood whimsy and grown-up wonderment. Join us in this reverie, and help make Dreamland a reality!

We also have a lot of great gifts for you! Look at that gorgeous Dreamland logo at the top of the page donated by the ever-so-talented Arin Fiskin Graphic Design. Wouldn't you love a tee, trucker hat or sticker with that on it? 

We've even got some higher ends gifts, like a custom pendant based on the designs Kate Raudenbush is creating for Dreamland, and your very own fire poofer! There's a lot of great stuff to choose from, no matter what your level of donation. 

Other ways you can help

There are lots of ways you can help out if you can't contribute funds. We're always looking for:

  • Volunteers in our shop at American Steel. Contact info@fluxfoundation.org for details!
  • Share this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, email, or carrier pigeon -- whatever gets the word out!
  • Make an in-kind donation of materials. We're especially in need of white exterior latex paint and varnish for wood.
story_txt:
Inspired by the wonder of childhood carnival rides, Dreamland is an immersive and interactive environment that encapsulates the energy of this year's Burning Man theme, the Carnival of Mirrors. A whimsical experience of vivid colors, dazzling light and flame transport participants to the world of spectacle and the carnivalesque.

You can still donate!Since we didn't reach our Indiegogo goal, FLUX still needs to raise about $10,000! You can still donate to help make magic! 
Go to: www.fluxfoundation.org/donateDreamland may have been created for Burning Man, but the vision of the Flux Foundation goes far beyond that of any event. What defines us is our devotion to creating art and community. We are a place where anyone, no matter how skilled, can walk in, join a project, and create art. We are constantly teaching and mentoring new artists and all we ask in return is that they create with us and give us their wholehearted participation while they’re in the shop. Your donations not only help to make the Dreamland installation possible, but they help to make the Flux Foundation itself financially sustainable and secure. Your support helps us keep the lights and helps us do what we love, and that means everything to us. 


Who we are
FLUX is a volunteer-based non-profit located in West Oakland, CA, at American Steel Studios, the largest industrial arts space on the West Coast. We've been building art together since 2010.
Our mission is to engage people in the designing and building of public art as a catalyst for education, collaboration and empowerment. We believe that every step in the art-making process is an opportunity to share ideas, knowledge and skills, and to create something monumental. 
Dreamland is our 14th sculpture together in five years. FLUX has an amazing track record of delivering incredible interactive sculptures. We've worked with diverse audiences around the country. In 2015, alone, we've created: 



Bloom! at the Philadelphia Zoo


Lacuna for the Bay Area Book Festival in Berkeley, CA



Check our our portfolio to see all our works.  





What is Dreamland? 

Undulating light and carnivalesque music spill across the desert night, beckoning participants to investigate. Bursts of flame punctuate the prismatic glow, seemingly random in duration and intensity. Upon approach, it becomes evident that the light, flame and music are connected parts of a singular attraction. 


Dreamland is an immersive environment with a kinetic sculpture at its center. It’s an unexpected oasis that disappears and reappears on the horizon, far away from the city streets in deep playa. Its perimeter is delineated by lampposts, kaleidoscopes and large, comfortable benches that provide a space to relax and enjoy an atmosphere of revelry. 
As participants interact with the sculpture, they discover that they control the movement of the piece by turning a circular, central railing, which moves the arms above head, imitating the mechanics of a swing carousel. During the day, spinning the sculpture creates shifting patterns of shade and light as the sun filters through a fabric canopy.  A soundscape that echoes the boardwalk and bygone carnivals fades in and out. At night, the atmosphere becomes electrified. As the spinning arms reach different velocities, the piece comes alive with fire and light. 






Dreamland is a collaboration

Dreamland is the result of a collaboration among over 40 different people contributing to engineering, design, wood, metal, fabric, flame effects, lighting, technology, logistics, project management, fundraising, marketing, crew care and a number of surprise elements yet to be revealed. FLUX's process is radically-collaborative, allowing for each person’s artistic input to become an integral and valued part of the whole while maintaining the artistic integrity of the artwork.
Visual design partner
We are also collaborating on the design elements of Dreamland with our dear friend and remarkable sculpture artist, Kate Raudenbush. Based in New York, Kate focuses on large-scale allegorical environments are created as an experiential set-piece for elevated human connection and social dialogue. We are thrilled to be working with her to bring this piece to life.
Sound design partners
A core element of the Dreamland experience is the soundscape that will draw participants in and envelop them in the space. Sounds of the carnival, the boardwalk and the sea coupled with ethereal music will be the soundtrack of the piece. We're partnering with a handful of incredibly talented, renowned DJs and sound designers who are each creating a unique track for the piece. Our collaborators include: Flavio Lemelle, Simon Shackelton, Sleight of Hands, Myagi, Shengi, and Jem Stone, among others. 


Funding partners
Dreamland started its life as Carousel, a project funded by the Abundance Foundation for the Project Zero Perspectives: Making, Thinking, and Understanding educator's conference at Lick Wilmerding High School in San Francisco in October 2014. FLUX was thrilled to partner with Abundance and Project Zero to create an interactive experience at the conference that engaged educators from across the country who are committed to design thinking and making in school curriculum. 


Carousel evolved to Dreamland as a project for the 2015 Burning Man event. Burning Man has provided a generous grant for this project to support the enhanced interactivity and placemaking experience that Dreamland has become.

What happens to Dreamland after its debut? 
The great part about Dreamland is that it is made to scale to different environments and different audiences. We envision it creating an ethereal, interactive, and magical experience for a small town or large city.
Dreamland inherently creates a communal gathering point, and its unique spectacle allows for social barriers to be lowered and new friends made. The sculpture is meant to be in any place where people gather, such as a park or a public plaza. It could even be in a hotel lobby or a school. It's a playful sculpture that can be easily modified for any application. The effects could also be adjusted seasonally, or for special occasions. 

   What we need We have received a generous grant from Burning Man for this project. We are looking to raise an additional $18,500 through this online campaign. Here's where your money will go: 


By supporting this art piece, you're supporting FLUX as a nonprofit committed to teaching people diverse art-making skills and transforming them into public artists. FLUX is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. As such, contributions made to this campaign for which you do not receive a gift are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

We've even got some higher ends gifts, like a custom pendant based on the designs Kate Raudenbush is creating for Dreamland, and your very own fire poofer! There's a lot of great stuff to choose from, no matter what your level of donation.

Contact info@fluxfoundation.org for details! Share this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, email, or carrier pigeon -- whatever gets the word out!

story:
We are well-established, independent LA area artists, who work in a wide range of mediums, and are collaborating on an innovative public art experience entitled Would Inglewood. The piece will activate the newly restored Agee Playhouse in Inglewood’s Edward Vincent Jr. Park over four separate periods throughout 2017. This work is important to us as an experiment in art and civic engagement—something both of us have been exploring in our creative practices. We believe that this is a timely endeavor as it incorporates a larger vision for Inglewood, a city facing the challenges of exponential development even while it recovers from the impact of negative stereotyping--a problem often faced by communities of color.

Would Inglewood was selected by the City of Inglewood through a competitive public art review process.  The selection committee praised Would Inglewood as ambitious and exciting, granting a budget of $12,500 and up to twelve weeks of access to the Agee Playhouse to prepare and present Would Inglewood.

We need to raise an additional $2,000:  $1,000 to pay for performers and $1,000 for assistants and materials. If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will go towards performers’ fees. Your support will enhance the artistic experience for everyone and be rewarded with pieces from the work for your collection.

We will be offering as incentives tee shirts and tote bags, flipbooks, jigsaw puzzles, CDs featuring video and audio works, and a limited edition, custom-designed popup book.

Would Inglewood combines installation, video, and live performance with interactive objects and activities to be experienced by visitors of all ages. A playhouse in a public park is an exciting and inspiring gift for any artist.  It is an opportunity for us to play and create, and invite others in to play and create with us.  Would Inglewood gives various people and communities a place to dream and invent through the portal of the playhouse, and from the cues conjured through our imaginations.  Would Inglewood is a work of magic that brings the city inside and turns it back out again transformed.  Your support, in addition to the grant from the City, also makes it possible for Would Inglewood to be open free to the public. You can check out our website at www.wouldinglewood.com.

The funds from the City have been earmarked for many non-art related expenses, such as insurance, marketing and publicity, all of which can consume much of a budget before paying for the things that create the art.  Additionally as our collaboration has developed over the past eight months, the scope of the work has expanded.  Where possible, we are using salvaged materials and loans of A/V equipment to reduce expenses. However, in order to truly follow the direction of the work, we must raise additional monies.

If financial support is not possible for you at this time, please help us get the word out about our Would Inglewood campaign by using Indiegogo share tools, posting to social media and sharing with your contacts. Thank you!

story:
Updated film above! With thanks to my friend George for the tune 'The Lentil Mount Show.' 

'The Shining Tree', part of a nonprofit arts organisation I founded in 2011, needs your help to launch a sustainable, supportive, locally relevant and meaningful Artists in Residence and exhibition programme in a studio, exhibition space and garden. My fundraising goal is £2000 GBP, you can help by donating £2 or more in return for some nice perks. I've a 2-minute film below which explains the story behind this adventure, if you'd care to read the longer story it's all set out below. Welcome to my campaign.

 

Hello. I am...

Debbie Taylor.

The Shining Tree Artists in Residence Programme

Part of my family home is two studios - one of those includes a gallery space, the other is a small off-grid studio and surrounding garden. I call these studios, gallery and garden 'The Shining Tree', the name was inspired by a poem 'when the light shifts' by artist Thomas A. Clark.  The Shining Tree is in a small ancient Cumbrian village called Gilcrux (gil-cruise) meaning 'hill retreat',  the place and community vibe are just beautiful.

A few years back, my family and friends supported me through a difficult and stressful time, which was when we collectively started to develop The Shining Tree, beginning with the garden - formerly an overgrown wasteland, and studio. For me this was a healing process, but I can't tell you how long I'd dreamed of sharing this space with other artists who need a bit of time and a bit of space and a bit of support to develop their practice. The idea of a somehow transformative space where artists would be well looked after, and left alone when they wanted, just grew from there, and from my own experiences. Since then, we've developed a second studio and gallery, also part of my family home... and I should say at this point, the family home is humble! It's a really small late 16th century cottage very slowly being taken back to its bones. The off-grid studio and garden are a moments walk away, while the second studio and gallery are in an outbuilding adjacent to the cottage. Altogether this is, I think, a place that's really rooted in the rural, with a close relationship to the rest of the county, Scotland and, even, the Scandinavian countries. 

What I can realistically achieve is as follows: 

I want to help support six Cumbrian and Scottish-based graduate artists over a three year pilot project. 

While The Shining Tree is based in Cumbria, the county has a historic, close connection to Scotland. The Shining Tree HQ overlooks the Solway Firth and the southern uplands of Scotland, among others the upland hill Criffel, to the south of Dumfries, is prominent; some describe this as a "mirror image" of the fell 'Skiddaw' in the Lake District.

The idea is that two graduate artists will be invited each summer at particular times to live and work here in the village of Gilcrux. I'm not going to be ageist!  participating graduate artists could be in their 20s, 30s, 40s and beyond. Artists might want to explore the history, heritage and landscape of West Cumbria; its relationship to the coast and wider county of Cumbria and its relationship to the west coast of Scotland, which is nearby, or they might be inspired to explore something completely different. At the end of their residency, at a later date, they will curate and host their exhibitions here at The Shining Tree (the exhibitions could even go on tour, wouldn't that be something.)

For the first year of The Shining Tree Artists in Residence programme, there are already two participating artists (you'll be hearing more about Helen Tuck and Martin Hill as this campaign develops). I've the studios and materials, a gallery space, IT equipment and support, and have even secured local self-catering accommodation, almost next door to the residency, so that participating artists feel comfortable. Should artists want to spend the odd weekend 'glamping' in the garden, I've got that covered too! So why do I need your help? 

My Fundraising Goal and How You Can Help

I don't believe that artists should pay to participate in residencies, or that residencies "should be the privilege of those with means" (An Xiao @anxiaostudio). I really need your help to award our first two participating artists a residency fee. 

There's a well-developed business plan and campaign strategy, and I've also applied for a small pot of public funding from both local and national organisations; but you'll already know that crowd funding has become necessary for non profits to raise funds in uncertain times. 

Here on Indiegogo I'm asking for £2000 GBP 

I know that transparency is important (and am happy to share some of my Business Plan with you on request.) In a nutsell, though, if I'm successful and are fully funded on Indiegogo, almost all of the funding will be awarded to the two resident artists this first year. 

Some of the funds will also contribute towards subsequent exhibition costs arising as a result of the residencies. 

Other Ways You Can Help

•Make some noise about my campaign by mailing your family and friends

•Use the Indiegogo share tools to promote my campaign on social media

•Mention the campaign on your websites, your blog posts, interview the artists or me if you fancy! 

Perks

I've a selection of perks, almost all of them have a connection to this beautiful place and its community. I'll post more details about the rewards as soon as I can.

Bee Good. Throughout summer, Bumblebees are in abundance in The Shining Tree garden which surrounds the off-grid studio... here's a picture of one of them. For every £15 you donate (this 'Bee Good' rewards specifically) I'll donate £2.50 to The Bumblebee Conservation Trust. Ok, you can save yourself £12.50 by donating £2.50 directly to The Bumblebee Conservation Trust but, bee good and help out two worthy causes ;)

 

 

Tendril - Poem on a Postcard. A handmade, handwritten and painted poem on a postcard. Each one is different, but all the poems are inspired by The Shining Tree garden. Here's a very short film about the making of a poem on a postcard, this one is about hedge bindweed...

 

Goose by Artist in Residence Martin Hill

An exquisite oil painting offered as a perk for a donation of £380. It's evident from many conversations and the resulting work of his residency to date that painter Martin Hill loves all animals... Here is a new work by Martin from the residency studio yesterday, 'Goose' (the subject lives with her friends in a beautiful garden nearby.) It's an oil on paper (should you choose this perk it will be bespoke mounted and oak framed.) Approx. size unframed 15' x 12".  
 

 

Sustainability, Risks and Challenges

I've to ensure this Artists in Residence pilot programme for the next three years is sustainable, and that means it must be professionally executed and delivered. 

Fundamentally, I believe I can deliver a sustainable programme when participating artists, as a result of their residencies, have exhibitions here at The Shining Tree studio and exhibition space... the artists sell their work and I take a modest commission. As a nonprofit, I'll be investing that commission back into the programme for subsequent years. 

What else am I going to do to help this become a sustainable project? Well, there's already a gallery and online shop, and throughout the year I'll be hosting workshops and fundraising events. You can read more about those by visiting theshiningtree.com

Almost certainly the biggest risk, the biggest challenge, is cashflow - having enough funds to properly cover this entire pilot programme (and that's where gallery exhibitions, my online shop, workshops and fundraising events come in). 

Of course, crowd funding is a big challenge too, I have to reach out to lots and lots of people, appealing to the generosity of family, friends and art-loving strangers.

I've also helped other arts organisations with fundraising and publicity, for a young nonprofit my small arts organisation has a decent track record.

story:
Send Horcrux to Galway!

Friends, fans, and fellow performers, I have been invited to bring my butoh-inspired creeptatstic number "Horcrux" to the first annual Galway Burlesque Festival! I am thrilled by this opportunity and am asking for donations to help me get there. 

FAQ's

  • For those who don't know me well, as Maxie Milieu, I have been performing Burlesque in Seattle for three years. This creative outlet built on my years of Ballet and Modern dance training. 
  • The piece "Horcrux" was initially created for Accio Burlesque 2014. It is one of my favorite pieces to perform. It is challenging, creepy, and unnerving,
  • This festival will be my International Debut!

For anyone who has been moved by this piece or any other I've performed, I would deeply appreciate your support. My hope is that through this trip I can expand my performance career. Travel opportunities are such a privilege and I am hoping to make the most of this adventure! 

What I Need & What You Get

The goal is Galway but the perks are yours!

  • I am fundraising to help cover the costs of my flight to Galway. Any amount helps! $1,700 will cover my round trip flight plus the fees associated with this fundraising campaign. Any amount above and beyond will contribute to other travel costs associated with the festival (food, lodging, ect.)
  • I've got some great perks for you all! Choreography, videography, photos, and a special cake sitting offer! I have a range of options for any budget. If you have considered my services before, now is the time! Your help is so appreciated.
Even if you can't financially contribute right now (believe me, I feel you) if you can share this campaign far and wide I will be profoundly thankful!
