story:
*Safety and Content Warning* This installation deals with themes of sexual violence, and may not be suitable for all viewers, specifically children. All sharp objects will be out of viewers’ reach.
 

Why "Touch"?

My name is Eliza Leighton. I am a visual artist and performer based in Philadelphia, and I work primarily in installations. I am currently working on “Touch” and asking for donations to help pay for materials.

“Touch” is a response to a letter that the father of Brock Turner, a Stanford student convicted of sexual assault, wrote to the media. In this letter, Turner’s father lamented his son’s conviction as an unfair consequence of a twenty-minute mistake, which spawned an anonymous letter written by the victim detailing the long-term consequences of Turner’s actions. “Touch” is my own similar response. It is about my battle with accepting, comprehending, living with, and overcoming the violent acts committed against me that have entirely changed who I am and will affect me for the rest of my life. 

In 2016, I created a version of this installation which occupied the third-floor balcony of the Community Education Center Theatre in West Philadelphia. Since then, I have been brainstorming ways to expand and refine it. I applied for grants and looked for a space to make it happen. I found the space, but the grants fell through. I decided to make the installation anyway, and hoped I would be able to save enough money to pay for the materials. However, some uncontrollable life factors got in my way: expensive vet bills, loss of food stamps, having more expenses than my monthly income could meet. Your donation will prevent me from going further into debt.

 

Where the Money Goes

The $1100 I am asking for will:

  • Pay for materials and supplies need to construct the installation
  • Pay the carpenter I’m working with for his time
  • Cover $100 in Indiegogo fees

If I do not receive the full $1100, the portion I do receive will pay for the supplies I have already gone into to debt to pay for.

 

The Impact

Donating to “Touch” will help me to create this piece that encourages conversations about sexual violence and the #metoo movement, and furthers awareness of this issue.

On a personal level, this is my first solo show! I’ve created other installations in the past, like “Nice White Lady”, “Little Debbie”, and “Plz Touch” (all featured in the video above). For each one, I managed to create large-scale and immersive works with very limited resources. Your contribution will help me to create the largest and most developed installation I’ve created yet!

 

Risks & Challenges

I recognize that putting the supplies for my installation on my credit card is risky, and many may find it to be an irresponsible decision. Unfortunately, there are few resources, other than grants, that exist to help artists pay for supplies. I encourage you to look at it this way: I feel that this project is important enough to take this risk, and will continue to work to pay off my debt.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also donate materials or your time! You can find the full list here: https://elizaleighton.cargocollective.com/News

 

I am primarily looking for the following items:

RED FABRIC

HARDWARE OF ANY KIND (nails, screws, bolts, door knobs, I'll take metal scraps as well)

PANTYHOSE/TIGHTS/NYLONS (of any color, can be ripped or have holes)

PLYWOOD

DRYWALL

 

If you're interested in volunteering during install (Thursday, September 27th - Friday, October 5th), you can sign up here: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/WLNJSKC

story:
Hematology was inspired by a genetic blood disorder called Hereditary Elliptocytosis that I was diagnosed with as a baby. For years, I've spent time in and out of the hospital at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital having my blood count checked and finding ways to cope with having a blood disorder. After seeing my blood smears during a hospital visit in 2016, I decided to create a line of printed travel wear garments inspired by irregular blood cells. Through the past few years of traveling and researching more about blood disorders, I found a need for versatile travel garments giving women the freedom to travel with ease and comfort. 

Deep oxbloods, purples, and maroons that represent the color of blood are present throughout the entire collection. As she travels, low crotch draped trousers, comfortable blazers are paired with printed mono jumpsuits and flowy blouses. Pockets and hidden panels are present on every single garment, including shirts. 

By donating to this campaign, you will help make this collection available to a wider market of women throughout the world. You will help change the trajectory of typical leisure travel wear garments into travel clothes that's luxurious, stylish yet completely comfortable.

If you wish to give to the making of the Hematology collection for the sake of giving, please do! However, I have a selection of amazing incentives for you to receive for your donation. Check out and select all of the perks you will receive for your donation in the column to the right.  The perks include fashion illustrated prints, fashion illustrated greeting cards, enrollment in my online painting classes, and the opportunity to host a painting workshop.

No contribution is too small. Contributing to this collection won't only help make traveling easier for women, but it will also help to bring more awareness to Genetic Blood Disorders, which affect mainly people from African and Mediterranean descent.

I have invested my entire life into becoming a fashion designer. After working in New York as a visual merchandiser and show room representative, I moved to London to pursue fashion design. A few years later, I attended American Intercontinental University (Now Regents University) and started working as a fashion illustrator. I've worked for brands such as NARS Cosmetics, The Peninsula Hotel Tokyo, High Line Park NYC, and Cameleon Visual Merchandising to name a few. I then continued my studies at London College of Fashion earning an honors degree in Fashion Design and Technology. Before attending London College of Fashion, I had the challenge of paying for tuition for school. Similar to now, I knew I had a very unique point of view and ideas that the world needed. So, I refused to let that stop me. I diligently looked for ways to fund the first year and with the help of family and friends, I was able to fund the first year of school through crowd funding. You can view the full video here: https://youtu.be/Fc7LhCLoX2o . I was born and raised in Memphis, TN.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can still help! Please repost this link via Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or simply spread the word to your family and friends.  I also have a selection of printed cotton and silk scarves available to purchase here: Travel Scarves

Thank you!

story:
Mother Tongue makes smart, super queer spectacles of beat punk storytelling. For the past year and a half we’ve been hard at work on a piece called ADLFDA and we’re thrilled to have the opportunity to share it at On the Boards as part of the Northwest New Works Festival in June. We're also in production on a short film of ADLFDA, shooting this Summer and into the Fall. We’re almost ready, but a little bit of support will go a long way towards making these dreams come true!

Self producing means we’re doing everything on a shoestring budget (don’t worry, we’re still going to blow your minds), but ADLFDA is a tech heavy piece of work and we could definitely use some support in covering our costs. Money raised here will go directly to: music gear, lighting rigs, video production, and costuming. Our biggest expenses are the complicated music wiring systems we’re using, and unavoidable video production costs, so even if we don’t hit this goal any funds raised will be used to help differ those costs. We've got some cool perks, check 'em out!

Raising this money not only makes it possible for us to make the film short and perform ADLFDA at NWNW, it makes it possible for us to perform it anywhere in the future! High quality video is a must for applying for performance opportunities, so having footage of the live performance at NWNW  is a super important step in being able to get our work in front of art lovers like yourself. Our short film will be screened first here in Seattle! We’ll send it to some film festivals as well, and it’ll become a part of our oeuvre.

So, your support really makes a huge difference right now and for the future of Mother Tongue.

The goal is $2000. Here’s the breakdown blow by blow:

Music Gear: $450

Lighting Gear: $50

Lighting Tech Support Fee: $150

Costuming: $150

Video Production: $835 (more would help!)

Audio Production: $110

Sound Engineering: $150

Indiegogo Platform and Transaction Fees: about $105

 

And of course if you want to support MT but can't make a donation right now you can always help us out by sharing this fundraiser and spreading the word! THANK YOU!

story:
What is Voices of Today?

Voices of Today is a is a five day festival with workshops, open mics, and showcases. It is the  newest addition to the set of festivals run by Spoken Word Canada, and its goal is to bring together youth poets from all across Canada to learn from community leaders and each other. This festival will take place July 24th-28th in what is colonially known as Toronto, ON.

Why is it important to support youth poetry?

Youth are not only the voices of the future, but also the voices of the present, the voices of today. They are already doing amazing and innovative things, yet they are often underestimated. Youth poets deserve space to discuss, learn, share, and feel validated in their ability to be a part of this community. Various workshops throughout the festival about writing, performance, and much more will give youth tools to go change the world with their words.

Poetry is a medium that amplifies the voices of marginalized and underrepresented groups. Spoken poetry as a medium originated with otherwise silenced and ignored groups, and is a way to speak about topics that aren’t often spoken on, in a community of acceptance. Spoken word poetry is a more accessible art form than classical English lit poetry and some other forms of art as it does not require expensive equipment, or higher education. These youth have important stories to tell and their short poems are often both educational for the privileged and a form of therapy/validation for the poets.

Spoken Word Canada currently hosts the Canadian Festival of Spoken Word in October, which is an all-ages festival and thus open to youth poets and attendees. However, many younger members face difficulties attending this event due to school both secondary and postsecondary. Voices of Today prioritizes and supports youth voices who are unintentionally excluded from other all-ages festivals, sometimes by scheduling that does not account for school, sometimes by licensed events that do not allow attendees below the provincial drinking age (usually 18 or 19). Everyone competing at Voices of Today will be below the age of 22 and all members of the Festival Organizing Committee 25 and under; we are specifically positioned to understand the needs of our membership base.

photo taken by Patrick Shannon (InnoNative.ca)

Who will be at the festival?

We will have workshops and features from:

  • D’Scribe the poet
  • Billie The Kid
  • Charlie Petch
  • Kay’la Fraser
  • Robyn Sidhu
  • Saleem Hussain Ansari
  • and many more!

Our lineup includes internationally touring poets, national champions, and slam veterans.

Why do we need your help?

Making all of this happen takes a lot of time, effort, and money. The small organizing committee is entirely made up of  volunteers but compensating artists and booking venues requires financial support. Voices of Today does not make any profit from the festival, and many organizers have invested their own money into this great cause. We are also in the process of applying for grants, but have yet to recieve any. Your donations help this festival exist! 

Exciting Announcement!!!! Voices of Today recieved a grant from the Ontario Arts Council to fund this years festival, all donations will go towards Voices of Today 2019.

How your donations directly help the cause

  • $150- lanyards for competing participants
  • $750- t-shirts for competing participants and volunteers
  • $300- refreshments for staff and artists
  • $300- posters
  • $2000- Booking venues
  • $1000- Supplies for events (A/V equipment, notebooks, pens, etc.)
  • $3000- Paying artists for their work

which adds up to $7500!

Note: These costs are estimates. Any additional funds raised will go into the bank account for Voices of Today 2019 to provide for this festival in the future.

Your support goes a long way to help us organize the show! We really appreciate any contributions to help us reach our target level of funding. Check out our multiple donation levels. If you have questions or comments about any of the perks, let us know in comments!

story:
Hello all!

I have been really cranking out illustrations lately, and this one is one I am particularly proud of, plus I think it will be a cute addition to anyone's pin collection (crybaby or not).

By donating, you will be helping me raise the funds to get these designs sent to production and made into a little, lovely piece of wearable art. I am wanting it to be a pin, but I would also really love to see it as a keychain (if funds allow) 

Along with getting first dibs on a Vibes pin, your donation comes with other perks depending on the amount you donate! Be sure to check out all the extra offers in the perks section!  

Can't donate? THAT'S OK! YOU CAN STILL HELP! 
Share this campaign, tag your friends in our instagram posts, tell people about The Crybaby Club, who we are and what we stand for. It helps so much and it is free :) 

 

Thanks for reading and
I hope you know how incredible you are.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I’m Kauser. I grew up going to the Library bookmobile every summer with my sisters and cousins. On hot afternoons after lunch— four square ball in hand and red wagon with 1 or more of us kids—we’d walk to the book mobile and check out books. I loved the book mobile, a movable library with books, crafts and easy access to the playground. Now as an adult, with my own kids, after studying urban planning and living in Detroit and Cleveland, I passed by vacant lots in town and wondered about ways to transform them into places kids would be drawn to.  What if —instead of just a bookmobile, you could walk into story books? And, that’s how Literary Lots started. My desire to walk into a life size pop-up book in my neighborhood where there was nothing in space before.

Here's how Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs Inspired us in 2013. Sandwich boats! Spagetti tubes! Tea Party with 6 foot flowers!

We’re starting with a HUGE vacant lot (150 x 500 ft) in Cleveland’s Slavic Village, a neighborhood deeply hit by the foreclosure crisis.  We are inspired by the strength of its community, and want to invite and include others in its revival spirit.
 

Here is the lot we're transforming. Can you imagine the robots there?

This lot will be transformed into a forest and tech town inspired by the book The Wild Robot by Peter Brown.Technology and artificial intelligence in the form of a robot force a group of island animals to reexamine identities, friendships, and their community. The Wild Robot makes us think about what it means to be alive, adaptable, forgiving and, most important, to be connected to one another. And, isn’t that what we need right now? Ways to connect with each other, and places to do this in. We believe “walking into a book” is inspiring. It changes the way people see and use space, and impacts their sense of community, belonging and creativity.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Our Literary Lot will include two areas of activities: the “robot” side and the “natural” side. Each side will feature uniquely built spaces for families to explore. The “robot” side will include robots as well as other “maker space” areas in which youth will be able to build their own robot inspired pieces. Across the lot, we will build a cave and more natural spaces providing room for families to get cozy and connect with books.

Cozy cave and a life size bird's nest full of books go here.

The Literary Lot will include a mural to be completed by the community during the opening days as well as a stage for poetry performances and movie nights.

What We Need & What You Get

This year we want to do a Literary Lots on a bigger scale in a Cleveland neighborhood devastated by the foreclosure crisis (the impact is still here) but supported by a tight knit community of residents, youth, and activists.

Good news is we’ve raised $45,000 through grants but still need another $10,000 to fully support the kids programming with:  more robust maker programming (the robot part of our lot), a food truck (kids like to eat),and additional time for artists to work directly with youth.

What do you get if you contribute? One-of-a-kind awesomely designed T-Shirts, stickers or posters by Jordan Wong. I mean like - very cool – your computer or water bottle will have THE best stickers of robots and nature.

All the funds will go to the artists and teachers directly. We’ll use the grant money we’ve raised already to put up the infrastructure and pay for a portion of the programming. Your money goes to help fund a deeper level of engagement and time from the artists we are hiring.

The Impact

It’s a strange thing to walk through a neighborhood street that’s a shadow of its former self. Knowing something was there and gone, and not sure what’s coming. In the vacant lots, we provide a temporary space to be creative and reimagine not only the space, but ways to read, write, make art and engage. Who doesn’t want to run into a huge space with a cave, life size bird nest, maker space, robots, the Wild Stage and an Airstream rehabbed to be our food truck?

For many youth in this struggling neighborhood,  museums and summer camps are not options. In Slavic Village —one of the poorer neighborhoods you’ll find in any city in the country— things are changing, slowly, creatively.  It’s alive with possibility. Over 20 nonprofit organizations are working to improve literacy and support youth with the wrap around services they deserve to be successful. Literary Lots fits right in. Literary Lots programming is free to all. Every day. All day. We did this before for 2 weeks, with over 1,200 people climbing into submarines we built inspired by 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea, or the 8 ft. sandwich boats inspired by Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs. You can help us build this place (that will be open 4 weeks) – magical, a little bit odd to see on an urban city street, and a whole lot awesome. Wouldn’t you want to say you helped bring robots and the wild to a city street in Cleveland?

Risks & Challenges

The grant funds we worked hard to raise are the backbone of this project, but it’s not enough. Artists and teachers deserve to be paid to provide this programming. Youth in this neighborhood have the potential to hang out in a cool space they will help create and enhance over the summer.

We have a dedicated team of planners, designers and artists doing amazing things in all kinds of different ways (check out partners: Soulcraft, Lake Erie Ink, Broadway School of Music, artists from Rooms to Let, Cleveland Orchestra Outreach Team, and artists from Ingenuity.) We just need a little more support and we’d love to add you to our list of supporters.  

We’ll use all the money we earn from this campaign to add programming. All the money goes to support the organizations building this. If we don’t raise it all, we’ll do the best we can with what we have. Can’t stop the creative process!

Other Ways You Can Help

Ok, we get it – you may LOVE this idea but can’t support it. You can still help us – likely you use social media way better than I do (hate to say but I’m being honest) so please help me spread the word.  Maybe something like this: “Hey (insert friend’s name here), you have got to support this project that brings books to life in vacant lots. And you will get some super cool robot swag.”  Share, share, share. Good karma will come your way. I’m sure of it. And we can all use some of that right now, right : ) Thanks for reading this far, and supporting however you can. Good vibes welcome. Money really welcome. Sincerest thanks. Really, we do appreciate your support of the creative community arts. Be well friends!

story:
Background

Started in 2018, the Freedom Through Art Collective (FTA) is a space designed to humanize and connect incarcerated artists across the country. Through a newsletter we send in once every month or two months, the artists are able to see each other's art, exchange creative ideas and feedback on their own art. FTA is made up of 20+ artists who correspond and creatively connect with one another with the overall goals of humanizing people in prison and supporting themselves financially through their artwork.

Art can be a therapeutic and financial lifeline for incarcerated artists, yet many work in isolation without an artistic community. Our goal for this collective is to change that. We started by asking ourselves, what principles from free world art collectives can we translate in the punitive prison industrial complex? Our artists may not be able to have the freedom that free world artists do, but we are working to establish a unique creative community to support, encourage, and challenge creative capacities. 

 

Pay incarcerated artists

Incarcerated artists often provide labor without compensation, especially in the free world. As free-world facilitators of this collective, we build intentional relationships with ourselves and between the artists, and use our power as free world activists to maintain connections within a system designed to isolate. Incarcerated artists deserve compensation for their labor, both for their creative thought and their artistic product.

 

We're asking for

  • $1000 directly to artists: pay each artist $50 immediately for their labor
  • $350 for supplies: frames and envelopes
  • $750 for stamps: this seems like a lot, but you don't know how much mail we send! We will also use this to cover the costs of shipping that artists pay to mail us their artwork.
  • $750 for prints and postcards: an investment that will yield more income for our artists
  • $150 for website fees

 

The impact

  • Artists will be paid for their work, resulting in less reliance on the prison system designed to dehumanize prisoners working for less than $1 per hour or sometimes just a $1 per day. 
  • By investing in their work, you will show that you CARE about them as human beings, which can mean more to them than you know.
  • You will be able to sustain this creative community by covering basic costs.

 

Other ways you can help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Make some noise about this campaign.
  • Share our website.
  • Check out the exhibit: https://mailchi.mp/053df26e9566/dreams-within-p...

And that's all there is to it.

story:
The Metabolizer

...is an open source rapidly deployable recycling center that is powered by trash. The Metabolizer consists of 6 inter-dependent systems that enable it to break down organic wastes and utilize them for energy, just like a mushroom does. The 6 primary systems are:

  • The Structure - A lightweight and rapidly deployable canopy structure.
  • The Shredder- An easy to build shredder box for shredding wastes.
  • The Reactor - A machine that reduces organic waste into bio-char and energy
  • The Generator- Any inverter generator, slightly modified to accept a gaseous fuel. 
  • The Battery Bank - A battery system for efficiently storing electrical energy.
  • The Trash Printer - a 3D printer that prints objects from shredded plastic flakes. 

 

Working together, these machines enable the system to power itself, using dry biomass as it's fuel source. A large component of what we call trash is burnable, organic material, such as paper, cardboard, grass clippings, leaves, and food scraps. The energy embodied in these common wastes is enormous, and when they are broken down in a special biochar reactor, they produce a clean, flammable gas that can power a generator with only minor modifications.

The generator powers the shredder, which shreds new material to feed to the reactor, which produces more gas to power the generator. The excess energy and heat produced in the process is used to heat water, cook food, play music, and power a special open source plastic recycling 3D printer that turns shredded waste plastics back into new and useful objects.

 

Hack the Planet!

The larger goal of the Metabolizer project is to develop a fully open source system that can meet as many human needs as possible that is easy to build, rapidly deployable, and able to be powered by waste biomass alone. It is an ongoing project until this technology is widely useable and available by anyone that wants to build one for themselves, their community, or needs one for, say, a pop-up and/or emergency situation.

The goal of this particular campaign is to raise money and support to deploy the first fully working iteration towards that goal, at the Portland Winter Light Festival at OMSI, February 6-8.

Over the course of that weekend, a small crew of volunteers will attempt to operate the Metabolizer for as long as possible, in an attempt to set the first world record for continuous operation of a Metabolizer.

The funding from this campaign will provide that team with a working budget to add critically needed upgrades to the Metabolizer before, during, and after the Portland Winter Light Festival. We are asking for help to buy the last chunk of critical parts. 

Currently, the most critical needs are:

  • Deployable Coroplast Canopy for weather protection. $300-$400
  • IoT sensors for real-time feedback on systems. $300-$500
  • Addressable LED lights to run off of the trash powered generator. $200-500

 

And the stretch goals are:

  • A Bigger, Better Generator - $800
  • A Better Battery Bank - $1200
  • A Waste Pelletizer - $600
  • Water Recycling Filtered Steambath - $600 (www.showerloop.org)

 

This is an ongoing project spearheaded by Sam Smith and a team of dedicated makers, and most of the parts are already in place. So beyond the more critical needs, these stretch goals are just that, stretch goals. They would make this project so, so much more awesome. No matter what you can contribute, it is a wonderful amount, and we salute and appreciate you. 

 

Is this real? Ongoing? How do I get more involved?

All of the parts of the Metabolizer are based on existing open-source projects that utilize readily available parts and easy to find materials. They all work, and the challenge now is getting them to work together, as part of a larger system, and that requires a lot of trial and error. The goal of this campaign is to build the a initial platform for further research and development of open source infrastructure systems. You can visit www.Metabolizer.org or www.TrashPrinter.org for documentation.

As a backer of this project, you will be supporting the ongoing development of the metabolizer platform, and will help make the project more effective, efficient, and easy to replicate. You will also get to see the outcome of your support at the Portland Winter Lights festival and beyond! If you would like to support this work on an ongoing basis, find opportunities to get involved, and stay posted on the ever evolving open documentation, you can follow the work on Patreon at www.patreon.com/disruptivelyuseful ! 

All of my work is open source and available to everyone, but Patrons get special little perks, like access to a Discord channel and raffles.

Campaign Rewards!

  • $1 = Undying gratitude! Thank you!
  • $5+ = Ritual Burning: we will vaporize a piece of trash into energy in your honor.
  • $50 = Cynicism Is Boring T-shirt: We will send this shirt in your size of choice to you!
  • $75 = SD card: An SD card with every bit of open-source documentation on this project.
  • $100 = Recycled Plastic Planter: Made on the recycled plastic 3D printing Trash Printer!

Come see The Metabolizer in person at the Portland Winter Light Festival on February 6-8th 2020, at OMSI, outside in the first gravel lot, in Portland, OR. See you there!
story_txt:
The Metabolizer
...is an open source rapidly deployable recycling center that is powered by trash. The Metabolizer consists of 6 inter-dependent systems that enable it to break down organic wastes and utilize them for energy, just like a mushroom does. The 6 primary systems are:


The Structure - A lightweight and rapidly deployable canopy structure.

The Shredder- An easy to build shredder box for shredding wastes.

The Reactor - A machine that reduces organic waste into bio-char and energy

The Generator- Any inverter generator, slightly modified to accept a gaseous fuel. 

The Battery Bank - A battery system for efficiently storing electrical energy.

The Trash Printer - a 3D printer that prints objects from shredded plastic flakes. 

 
Working together, these machines enable the system to power itself, using dry biomass as it's fuel source. A large component of what we call trash is burnable, organic material, such as paper, cardboard, grass clippings, leaves, and food scraps. The energy embodied in these common wastes is enormous, and when they are broken down in a special biochar reactor, they produce a clean, flammable gas that can power a generator with only minor modifications.
The generator powers the shredder, which shreds new material to feed to the reactor, which produces more gas to power the generator. The excess energy and heat produced in the process is used to heat water, cook food, play music, and power a special open source plastic recycling 3D printer that turns shredded waste plastics back into new and useful objects.
 

Hack the Planet!
The larger goal of the Metabolizer project is to develop a fully open source system that can meet as many human needs as possible that is easy to build, rapidly deployable, and able to be powered by waste biomass alone. It is an ongoing project until this technology is widely useable and available by anyone that wants to build one for themselves, their community, or needs one for, say, a pop-up and/or emergency situation.

story:
Who I Am and What I'm Doing

My name is Daniel. I am a self-taught artist in Las Vegas. Throughout my life I have been painting. Until recently I've never considered exploring the option of displaying or selling art.

In July I was given the opportunity to display my art for the first time publicly at a gallery in Las Vegas. The show ran for a month. The feedback was positive and I sold a few pieces. I also created a website UncalmArt.com.

I was then accepted into another show in September and displayed a few pieces. I want to continue this journey and travel to other shows outside Las Vegas.

Why I Need Your Support

I am seeking support for costs related to entering, traveling to, and displaying at art shows. I have already invested in prints of some of my favorite recent works, marketing material, a website, and more.
I have been accepted into an art show in Los Angeles that will take place in late November.  Any funds raised here will be used for the travel costs and costs associated with displaying at this show and hopefully others in the near future

The Impact

The funds raised here will help me to continue creating and find an audience.

If this campaign goes well I know there is an immediate future for my art. If it doesn't go well... then I will regroup, change course, and determine another path to try.

Whatever happens I will continue to create art that I find visually appealing and work to find an audience for it.

Risks & Challenges

Your investment in me is secure. Any perk listed is ready to go. I haven't listed anything that I am not able to offer almost immediately.


Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps my art does not excite you. But maybe you know someone that might enjoy it. Please share this project and/or my website via Facebook, Twitter, email, Google+, LinkedIn, carrier pigeon, Pony Express, Morse code, smoke signal, or good old fashioned conversation.

Website: UncalmArt.com


What you get

For your donation I will gladly respond with perks.

Perk 1 - $5 - Limited edition 5 Card set - Free shipping
I had a limited edition (only 50 printed) set of 5 cards printed specifically for this Indiegogo campaign. Each is an example of my favorite pieces. 5.5 x 4.2" each, double sided, high quality.

 

Print 1 through 6 - Square giclée prints from my silhouette series
  • Each is signed and numbered (limited edition of 25 each)
  • Original artwork pieces are all 24 x 24 inches
  • Image size = 6.5 x 6.5", paper size = 8.5 x 8.5", sized to perfectly fit standard 12 x 12" frames found at most craft or frame store.
  • Professionally printed with archival inks on high quality acid free paper.

Print 1 - Blue with red heart

Print 1 shown in frame
Print 2

Print 3

Print 4

Print 5

Print 6

Print 7 and 8 - Giclée prints
  • Each is signed and numbered (limited edition of 25 each)
  • Original artwork pieces are all 24 x 48 inches
  • Image size = 5 x 10", paper size = 7.5 x 12.5", sized to perfectly fit standard  frames found at most craft or frame store.
  • Professionally printed with archival inks on high quality acid free paper.
Print 7

Print 8

Print set - Set of 6 giclee prints
  • A set of 6 square prints of my silhouette target series. Each is limited to 25 pieces. All hand signed and numbered.
  • These are the same prints shown for prints 1 through 6. You can see in this picture they are printed, wrapped, and ready to go.



ADDED 09/29/15

Why "UNCALM"?

The word uncalm is the name of a song by my favorite band, 311. I have been a rabid fan since I first heard them over 18 years ago. Their message of unity, positivity,  celebration, and respect has influenced many aspects of my life. My love of art and 311 have been constant joys in my life for longer than any other interest. Many  hobbies and loves have come and gone but I'm not sure I've gone more than a day without listening to 311.

When I decided to start a website I wanted to find a name that represented my art. I didn't want to simply use my name. A 311 song or quote was an obvious choice and I think uncalm fits my style.

"Stay positive and love your life" from Jupiter by 311.

story:
Short Summary

We are moving!

The Black History Museum and Cultural Center of Virginia (BHMVA) was founded in 1981.  For the past 20+ years the museum has been located at 00 Clay Street in the  Historic Jackson Ward area of Richmond VA.  We have outgrown our space in this beautiful two story Federal Revival house built in 1885. This house, once the Black branch of the Richmond Public Library and named for Rosa Dixon Bowser (one of the first black licensed teachers in Richmond, Virginia ) has served us well.

We are fortunate that our new home which will triple our exhibit space is just as rich in history. The Leigh Street Armory was originally built for a black militia in 1895 and also located in Jackson Ward.  We began renovations to transform the space in September 2014 and are looking forward to moving in December of 2015.


What We Need & What You Get

We need your help!

Our capital campaign and annual fund raising are in full swing and we thank everyone who has supported us!   It is this support that has helped us get this  far.  As we continue to move toward our Bright Future, and strive to realize our Bold Vision of being the only museum in Virginia dedicated to telling the story of African Americans and people of African descent we need additional funding and your help!  

As we work on renovating and retrofitting the Armory building we will also be developing our art programming, branding, and exhibits to properly  invest in our  infrastructure.  

Your Mission 

You can make a difference! Once you have donated, please support the campaign by letting others know how their contribution will also make a difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out, tell friends, and family to join us.  Become a member of BHMVA today and please like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and IG at "BHMVAmuseum".   Help us reach our goal any contribution would help!

story:
Our Story
Little Bear Hill has grown out of a combined vision to bring together the artistic community as it exists around a shared table and a modern studio, offering 21st century cutting edge equipment to expand the possibilities available to our residents and members. 

The studio and artist-in-residency program at Little Bear Hill pulls together elements of a traditional printmaking studio and combines them with new technology useful to a large cross-section of artistic mediums. The addition of 3D printers, a laser cutter, and a CNC router bring the studio to the forefront of artistic practice.

Located in the Scenic Columbia River Gorge on a 16-acre farm and cherry orchard, Little Bear Hill is nestled near the top of a ridge in The Dalles, Oregon. With the Cascade mountain range to the west and the Oregon High Desert to the east, we are blessed with an incredible number of sunny days and endless inspiration.

Dylan McManus brings over 15 years of experience in printmaking and installation art to Little Bear Hill, with his work in several collections and exhibitions around the world. For the last decade Dylan has taught graduate and undergraduate printmaking students as an Adjunct Faculty and Instructional Technician at the State University of New York at New Paltz, while also working privately as a master printmaker in both traditional and digital methods.

Bethany Ayres-McManus works alongside Dylan, directing operations on the orchard and farm. Beth merges the crafts of farming and food into the culture of the studio by offering residents and guests access to sustainably grown farm to table fare as well as participatory events focused on the shared acts of art and eating. 

Guthrie Wilder McManus is our Public Relations Expert, Style Coordinator, and Party Planner.  Currently he is working on a series of dance moves for Thank You videos and educational outreach.


Our Request (What We Need & What You Get)

We need your help to build our studio and acquire the rapid prototyping equipment that will move our print studio into the post-digital age.  This project has been in development through various stages over the last four years, and acquiring the land and location was the biggest initial hurdle.  Now that we have a gorgeous location to work from we are moving forward with our dream.  Our goal for the studio space is to create a modern, aesthetic, and creative environment that is both inspirational as well as sustainable in both function and design.  We will be up-cycling an existing structure on the farm into this space, and then creating a studio environment that offers artists a natural flow between traditional and new media printmaking processes.  Beyond the money required for the studio itself and relocating from the East to West Coast, the equipment we hope to acquire through our crowd funding include a medium format Laser engraver, two medium format 3-D printers one using FDM technology, the other utilizing SLA printing, and we also hope to acquire enough funding to purchase a 4x4’ CNC router.

The good news about our Indiegogo fundraiser is if we come up short of our goal, we have enough space in the existing house on the farm to set up a functional studio that can house one resident at a time.  This is exciting because it means if we’re not initially able to realize our vision for the larger space, we will be able to use the funds we do raise to acquire equipment and thus offer the world access to Little Bear Hill as we continue work on the larger studio. This multi-directional approach toward building the space allows us to be flexible given the success of our initial fundraising, grant writing, and growing season. If we are not able to meet our fundraising goal we are still able to adapt our initial approach  toward the best possible outcome for Little Bear Hill. 

The Vision Of Little Bear Hill (The Impact)

Little Bear Hill is our invitation for the global art community to collaborate in answering : “How will  Art evolve into the 21st Century?”  Our space will offer residents in various career stages the opportunity to work in a collaborative studio environment where shared innovation and dialogue becomes a spring board into new artistic revelations.  As we grow we will offer more diverse forms of residency opportunities. These programs range from a live-in, merit based emerging artist residency for one talented individual who wants to live on site while working towards their artistic goals, to multiple residency opportunities ranging in length from a single weekend to a month long focused study. 

Little Bear Hill will be the first residency in the United States with the combined vision of offering traditional artists access to post-digital tools with a master printmaker available for hands on work, and emerging artists a mixed traditional and new media studio to provide them with the means to work in a professional print studio in an idyllic setting.  Dylan’s work as a global artist has seen him coordinate projects that span continents and connect multiple individuals with the end goal being a final exhibition.  He also comes at this project with a decade of teaching and technical experience.

              


The Hurdles "Challenges"

Our biggest challenge is moving to Oregon. However, we’ve done it before and we’ll do it again. After moving onto the farm and into our new house in The Dalles we have the challenge of building the studio. The property itself lies within the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area and we will need to gain extra permits for building the studio. The commission governing the National Scenic Area is concerned primarily with environmental impact and land use, which is great for us as we plan on building a sustainable structure with a small environmental footprint.  The studio will combine up-cycled materials and a low-impact aesthetic that will merge seamlessly with the natural environment.  


Final Thoughts...

It is with great excitement and anticipation that we launch this crowd funding campaign. We would like to thank you immensely for your time and consideration in funding our project. Please remember that every little bit helps, and that includes all of your support in sharing this project with others. Spread the word!! 

Some Of Our Perks:

Mike Lawrence
"Boy In A Tree"
Pigment Print
11x17", Signed Edition of 10, 2015
Mike Lawrence Illustration

Jon Irving
"If I Remember, It's Only Being A Kid"
Relief, Silk Screen, Chine Colle
11x15", Signed Artist Proof 5 Available, 2014
Irvingprints.com


Dylan McManus
"Skull In Couture (Spring, Fall, or Summer)"
Silk Screen
11X16.5", Signed Prints from Edition of 5 (3 available), 2013
dylantmcmanus.com

MacManHash
Untitled
22x30", Relief, Signed E.V. of 5 (3 available), 2014


Arthur Hash
"Title Pending"
3.75x1.5", Painted Steel, 4 Available, 2010
arthurhash.com

Little Bear Hill
"Trucker Hat Hot Sauce"
3 Flavors, Kind of Hot (right), Hot (middle), and Really Hot (left)
Small Batch, Numbered, Hand Printed Woodcut Labels, 30+ Available

Keep Checking Back as we update with new perks as our campaign moves forward.Visit us at:

Website: http://littlebearhill.com/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/LittleBearHill
Etsy: https://www.etsy.com/shop/LittleBearPress

The property itself lies within the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area and we will need to gain extra permits for building the studio. The commission governing the National Scenic Area is concerned primarily with environmental impact and land use, which is great for us as we plan on building a sustainable structure with a small environmental footprint.  The studio will combine up-cycled materials and a low-impact aesthetic that will merge seamlessly with the natural environment.  


Final Thoughts...
It is with great excitement and anticipation that we launch this crowd funding campaign. We would like to thank you immensely for your time and consideration in funding our project. Please remember that every little bit helps, and that includes all of your support in sharing this project with others. Spread the word!! 
Some Of Our Perks:

Mike Lawrence"Boy In A Tree"Pigment Print11x17", Signed Edition of 10, 2015Mike Lawrence Illustration


Jon Irving"If I Remember, It's Only Being A Kid"Relief, Silk Screen, Chine Colle11x15", Signed Artist Proof 5 Available, 2014Irvingprints.com

Dylan McManus"Skull In Couture (Spring, Fall, or Summer)"Silk Screen11X16.5", Signed Prints from Edition of 5 (3 available), 2013dylantmcmanus.com



MacManHashUntitled22x30", Relief, Signed E.V. of 5 (3 available), 2014
Arthur Hash"Title Pending"3.75x1.5", Painted Steel, 4 Available, 2010arthurhash.comLittle Bear Hill"Trucker Hat Hot Sauce"3 Flavors, Kind of Hot (right), Hot (middle), and Really Hot (left)Small Batch, Numbered, Hand Printed Woodcut Labels, 30+ AvailableKeep Checking Back as we update with new perks as our campaign moves forward.Visit us at:Website: http://littlebearhill.com/Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/LittleBearHillEtsy: https://www.etsy.com/shop/LittleBearPress

story:
Festival 23: Convergence of Disco

...the weekend of 23rd July 2016

...at a secret outdoor location in the north of England

An interactive celebration of literature and the arts; of theatre, playshops and music inspired by the Discordian movement; a society of philosophers, theologians, magicians, scientists, artists, clowns and similar maniacs who are intrigued with Eris, Goddess of Confusion, and with her doings.

Inspired by the Cosmic Trigger play and the associated Conferestival, we like to think that Festival 23 is an (il)logical progression of that wonderful weekend and we want NotWork 23 to be a means of keeping those connections together.

We've already got a fantastic group of co-conspirators on board with activists, artists, comedians, musicians, poets, puppeteers and writers squeezing their creative juices into our collective psychedelic cocktail. From the sublime to the ridiculous.

Sound fun? Interesting? Enlightening?

We hope so and we want you involved. Yes, that's right, YOU!

The matter of making magic

The aim of Festival 23 is not just to hold a party in the open air, but to realise and strengthen a burgeoning grassroots network of Discordians, to re-connect the others and grow the Rotten Apple Corps. To embrace the chaos of a collective, empower one another in our creative endeavours. To entertain, encourage and to support each other in challenging our own reality tunnels. Then maybe we'll start an annual party to celebrate us coming, and remaining, together.

Wherever you are around this wonderful globe you can help get this shit off the ground. There's lots of ways you can support the birthing of this beautiful beast and we've some splendiferous perks to reward your support.

Festival 23 will be like no other. Not only will it be a not-for-profit endeavour, but most importantly, Festival 23 will be owned, designed and managed by the people who participate. Through NotWork 23 (like a network, just more fun), every committed member will have an equal voice, an equal say and an equal stake in Festival 23. £23 a year opens the door and allows you to become a co-creator of a truly unique happening. How good will that feel? To feel ownership of something magic – something HEROIC.

What's in it for you? What's in it for me?

This is a litmus test. A temperature check.

We are committed to making something special happen on the weekend of the 23rd July 2016, but exactly what happens will be determined by the interest, skills, creativity and resources of the people in the room. Of the people in NotWork 23.

Throw your hat in the ring by pledging to support our campaign and we'll know we're on the right track. Throw YOURSELF into the ring by pledging £23 or more and becoming a member of NotWork 23, and you can help to lay the track, set its direction and maybe even design and build your own station on the route.

And you can get cool badges and t-shirts and books and all that shit too.

The more that we raise through this campaign, the bigger our ambitions for Festival 23 can be. We've put a fundraising target of £5,000, but it could just as easily have been £23,000. Even if we reach our target, you can keep giving, knowing that the extra funds will help us make things bigger and better and, even more importantly, will help us to keep ticket prices as low as possible so that those who have little will still be able to jump in with both feet.

And if we don't make our target? We'll put on an equally magical, HEROIC event for a smaller group of people. Everyone's a winner.

So what next?

Get involved. Support the birth by joining Notwork23, you'll be fundamental, (the good sort of fundamental), in empowering similar souls and encouraging like-minds. Come to our WOW POW in November to help to design Share this campaign and make sure the right people KNOW.

Tell them... Come on in. The waters lovely.

Tell them... Come in number 23, your time is up.

Hail Eris!

story:
Just like the great George Costanza (portrayed by the incredible Jason Alexander) once wanted to do a "show about nothing", I just want to raise money for nothing. Not for a potato salad. Not for a prayer. No specific goals. Not even an idea how to spend it yet. I'm just doing it because I can. We can call it a social experiment, a form of art. Let's just see where this might lead us.

So if you have some extra bucks that you can afford to throw here, just do it! Let's make this happen!

story:
We have reached our goal. The video of the interview will be edited and shared! 

I am humbled and grateful to enjoy such a remarkable community of support. We reached our goal in less than a week! I can't wait to share the video with all of you. Will keep you posted on the progress of editing. Our first team meeting is on May 13. 

In the meantime, this campaign will remain open till the end of May. 

Your additional contribution can help

  • complete the photographic part of my own documentation, 
  • edit other artists’ interviews, and 
  • preserve and teach the ancient techniques of Tibetan appliqué. 

Select a "perk" on the right to direct your contribution to the activity that inspires you most. You're not limited to the dollar amount shown in the perk description. After selecting your direction, you are welcome to add whatever additional contribution you like!

**************************
Below is the original project description. As promised, any contributions received in excess of the project goal will go toward furthering the artistic and educational projects of Leslie's Threads of Awakening and of Focus on the Masters.

**************************


First things first... 

 why have I called you here?

I had the most amazing experience last month being documented by Donna Granata of Focus on the Masters. On March 28, after extensive preparation, Donna interviewed me before a live studio audience. The loving energy was palpable, encouraging me to open my heart and share my story more clearly and powerfully than I have before. I want to make this interview available, in whole and in segments, to anyone who may be inspired by it.
The four-camera video recording needs to be professionally edited before it can be shared. I and Focus on the Masters are asking for your help in getting this done.


Why you might want to fund this project...

  • Fund it because you came to the Spotlight, were fascinated and want to listen again.
  • Fund it because you couldn’t make it and want to watch yourself.
  • Fund it because you want to share it with friends.
  • Fund it because Focus on the Masters is the only biographical archive of its kind in the country, illuminating the lives of artists and inspiring others to the diversity of creativity.
  • Fund it because you love Tibetan art.
  • Fund it because you love textiles.
  • Fund it because you love Leslie.
  • Fund it because you love Donna.
  • Fund it because you’re inspired when others open their hearts and share what’s meaningful to them.
  • Fund it because you think artists’ stories need to be told and that they merit preservation.
  • Fund it because the dakinis whispered ‘yes’ in your ear...


About Focus on the Masters

Focus on the Masters (FOTM) is a non-profit, 501(c)(3), art appreciation program that documents, preserves and presents the works and lives of accomplished contemporary artists. The FOTM archive includes photographic portraits, audio and video interviews, artwork and biographical research that encompass each artist's experiences, reflections and development. Not only is this rich resource made available to researchers, but FOTM also seeks to present it to a broad public through educational programs for all ages, notably the Learning to See Youth Outreach program, a monthly Artist Spotlight Series, exhibitions, publications, and an extensive resource library. FOTM is the only biographical resource project of its kind in the country. Its multiple projects are linked by a common mission: to demonstrate the importance of the arts to a healthy society by bringing highly accomplished artists to the forefront of the community. 



About Me 

(Here's where I write about myself in third person)

Leslie Rinchen-Wongmo is an American textile artist working in an ancient Tibetan tradition. In her fabric thangkas, the sacred Buddhist images of Tibetan thangka paintings are rendered in vivid mosaics of silk. One of the only westerners trained in the rare Buddhist art of silk appliqué thangka, Leslie is passionate about the preservation and evolution of this cultural tradition. Her story is the subject of the acclaimed documentary film, Creating Buddhas: the Making and Meaning of Fabric Thangkas. And her thangkas have been exhibited in museums and dharma centers worldwide. Leslie's work is simultaneously traditional and contemporary. Over the course of two decades, her nomadic life has brought her full circle from California to India, through Italy, and back home to California. Each place has touched her and influenced her vision. She mentors students around the world through her Stitching Buddhas Virtual Apprentice Program. And her Threads of Awakening Weekly Wake-ups bring a weekly dose of inspiration to many. Learn more and view Leslie's artwork at ThreadsofAwakening.com. 

From the Artist Spotlight invitation: 

When Leslie Freilich's name was changed by a Tibetan lama to Rinchen-Wongmo it was not done to deny her past but rather to catalyze a spirituality that she had been seeking. This Tibetan name means Precious Empowered Woman and reflects Leslie's embrace of life and the philosophy of Buddhism. She creates thangkas, vibrantly colored, meticulously sewn, sacred fabric scrolls that act as objects for meditation, for contemplation. Creating a thangka (sounds like Tonka) involves techniques that are centuries old and a keen understanding of and appreciation for spiritual tradition. Over the years Leslie's style has morphed from creating very traditional scrolls to a more modern, personal style that evokes both the ancient art form and modern quilting techniques. Whether ancient or modern, however, all of her art is infused with joy and serenity. 



About the Artist Spotlight

Each year, Focus on the Masters selects ten "Master Artists" for extensive documentation, a process that culminates with the Artist Spotlight interview series.  
FOTM Master Artists are selected based on criteria that include mastery of their craft, respect from their peers, and their historic role in the life of the community.  FOTM also gives consideration to selecting a group of artists who practice a variety of media so that all creative expressions are represented. 
Each artist’s documentation begins with the gathering of biographical materials. Resources can include publications, essays, published work, slides, CDs, video recordings and ephemera of all types. These materials form the basis for each artist’s file. Additionally, Donna Granata personally interviews the artist in recorded oral histories and at the Artist Spotlight evening, which is video taped in front of a live audience. The Artist Spotlight Series provides the public with an opportunity to meet the artists and experience their work first-hand and allows the artist to exhibit original work, share personal experiences, and give advice to the gathered audience.

The Project 

(What your contribution will pay for)

Digital recordings from four cameras will be brought together into a seamless whole and interspersed with images of the art and story.

With your help, we'll edit and publish the entire hour-plus conversation, making it available to the public and researchers, both online and offline.

We'll also edit and publish selected “shorts” online. These are segments in which Leslie responds to particular questions on topics such as trichotillomania, silkworms, and how to view images of enlightenment.

Production of these videos will help both Leslie and FOTM promote their good work in the world and will strengthen their ability to acquire funding for future projects.

DETAILS:

Donna Granata and the whole FOTM team do a spectacular job gathering information and interviewing. 

They add meticulous stage production, lighting, sound, and cinematography…

But these multi-camera, multi-track recordings are not really usable until they’re edited, and that requires funding. 

Editing the full-length interview will cost about $1500. 

I’ve budgeted another $400 to create short segments for quick viewing on single topics, for gathering supportive imagery and ‘B-roll’ video, and for getting everything published on the web. 

Finally, because it costs money to raise money, I've budgeted $300 to cover the costs of running this campaign.

Any contributions received in excess of the project goal will go toward furthering the artistic and educational projects of Leslie's Threads of Awakening  (75% ) and of Focus on the Masters (25%).

Your help is NECESSARY and APPRECIATED. Look in the sidebar to your right for giving levels and for our gestures of thanks!


Comments from some people who attended Leslie's March 28 Artist Spotlight:

Your interview was the best I've seen.  -- Paula Spellman
I sit in the audience each month and wonder if I could sit in front of 100 people, baring my soul and heart. I am not sure I could, but I greatly admire your courage. Your art is superb and reflects your life. Thank you for sharing yourself and your art with us. It was a special evening in many ways.  -- Jo Ellen Lee
...so real, earnest, impassioned, caring, open to the world to share... and more... Thank you for sharing, Leslie. I loved being there in the room that you so richly and fully filled.  -- Kathleen Johnsen
Thank you again and again for your openness and sharing of your self and your loving beautiful work with all of us in the Focus on the Masters interview.  -- Jean Bramer
Being my first time, I was very impressed with FOTM and Donna Granata in Ventura. Great job to all! -- Liz Galvan
I've always been a supporter of Focus on the Masters and have attended many Artist Spotlights. But now, having participated in the process, I feel more deeply supportive than ever. Donna Granata does an extraordinary service with great humility, unwavering presence, and multifaceted meticulousness. AND we share a birthday! -- Leslie Rinchen-Wongmo
So nice to learn more about you and your art. Jayne in particular was really fascinated with all the talk about stitchery and fabric. Thanks for both your talent and your gracious and gentle spirit. -- Tim Pompey
Fantastic artist. I loved hearing about her journey and seeing her beautiful art pieces. -- Gerri McMillin
Another wonderful Focus on the Masters Artist Spotlight interview. Thank you to everyone who came out to listen to the life story of Leslie Rinchen-Wongmo. The love for this amazing art artist was palpable.        -- Donna Granata
I want to edit this one! -- Francisco Munoz, cinematographer


Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you donate yourself or not, there are lots of additional ways you can help! 
  • Share this campaign with your friends on Facebook and other social media. 
  • Email the link to others you think may be inspired to contribute.  
  • Become a Focus on the Masters member.
  • Commission a thangka ;-)

Your help is NECESSARY and APPRECIATED. Look in the sidebar to your right for giving levels and for our gestures of thanks! Or choose to contribute whatever tax-deductible amount you like.

My deepest thanks!

story:
Anteism's Second Augmented Reality Book


Anteism is ready to print their second augmented book, featuring the work of multi media artist Frances Adair Mckenzie. The book will be 48 pages, 8x10 inch hardcover, color printing, with foil debossing and augmented reality media on it's pages!


This project will be an exploration of how augmented reality can change the reader's experience of an Artist book. This project is Anteism's first book combining sculptural works, performance, installation and video work. A full exploration of the printed page through new media including emphasis on tactility, movement and sound.

What is an AR Art Book?


Augmented reality uses the printed page, hand held devices, inter-activity and digital content to fuse the gap between digital artists and the print and publishing industry. Augmented print is an innovation to the changing face of art books, extending how media art can be communicated and experienced. 
Augmented reality allows readers to view digital content, such as a gif or animation, using their own tablet, smartphone or wearable device. The viewer simply downloads Anteism's custom app onto their device and the program uses image recognition to retrieve and play corresponding videos.

Watch this video of an Augmented Reality ART project, created in collaboration with our inter-active designer Takeshi Mukai. 



About the Artist


Frances Adair Mckenzie is a multi-media artist who combines genres and technologies as a means to invoking fantastical internal and external worlds.  Her work in motion-design, animation and immersive installation evokes a din of concentrated effects that meld both high and low cultural references and technologies.

Frances Adair Mckenzie lives and works in Montréal. She attained a diploma in New Media from B.C.I.T. and a Bachelor of Fine Arts from Concordia University. The National Film Board of Canada has commissioned her animations and her work has been exhibited at the Musée de art Contemporain de Montréal, and the Société des Arts Technologiques. Frances also collaborates with Aleks Schurmer, to form the collective 1699. The collective's aim is to take classical music from the confines of the modern concert hall and reclaim it as a popular medium in the form of a digital Baroque opera. 


We hope you share Anteism’s excitement for this project and will help us support the dedicated artists who contribute their work and ingenuity! 



Where will your help go?

We are seeking your help to produce this book!

This Indiegogo campaign will help with all levels of production for this project including; design, printing, material and assembly costs. 

30% of the budget will go to the development of a tailored application for the augmented reality artist book. This will be available as a free download in the App store.

30% will be used for book production costs, including printing, binding and foil debossing.

20% for design of both the digital and print and content.

10% towards communication and publicity.


The Impact


  • By backing this campaign, you will in effect be helping pave the way for future AR books and helping to re-conceptualize how publishers work with digital artists.
  • As a contributor you will be kept up to date on the innovative and exciting process of producing this work  - everything from traditional book making to the creation of new augmented reality publishing techniques!
  • Anteism is working with programmer and inter-active designer Takeshi Mukai to create a tailored application with higher resolution and designed specifically for the Artist book experience.
  • Take A look at Anteism's first Augmented reality book completed in the spring of 2015, featuring the work of Montreal based gif artist Scorpion Dagger.

PERKS!


Anteism has put together an exciting list of donation perks, including the finished Augmented Reality Art Book, original pieces and limited edition print. We assure all of their projects and recognizes their supporters with exciting pieces of art that will be delivered to your address! 



Thank You for supporting Anteism's second Augmented Reality Book project !!!
story_txt:
Anteism's Second Augmented Reality Book



Anteism is ready to print their second augmented book, featuring the work of multi media artist Frances Adair Mckenzie. The book will be 48 pages, 8x10 inch hardcover, color printing, with foil debossing and augmented reality media on it's pages!


This project will be an exploration of how augmented reality can change the reader's experience of an Artist book. This project is Anteism's first book combining sculptural works, performance, installation and video work. A full exploration of the printed page through new media including emphasis on tactility, movement and sound.

What is an AR Art Book?


Augmented reality uses the printed page, hand held devices, inter-activity and digital content to fuse the gap between digital artists and the print and publishing industry. Augmented print is an innovation to the changing face of art books, extending how media art can be communicated and experienced. 


Augmented reality allows readers to view digital content, such as a gif or animation, using their own tablet, smartphone or wearable device. The viewer simply downloads Anteism's custom app onto their device and the program uses image recognition to retrieve and play corresponding videos.

Watch this video of an Augmented Reality ART project, created in collaboration with our inter-active designer Takeshi Mukai. 




About the Artist


Frances Adair Mckenzie is a multi-media artist who combines genres and technologies as a means to invoking fantastical internal and external worlds.  Her work in motion-design, animation and immersive installation evokes a din of concentrated effects that meld both high and low cultural references and technologies.

Frances also collaborates with Aleks Schurmer, to form the collective 1699. The collective's aim is to take classical music from the confines of the modern concert hall and reclaim it as a popular medium in the form of a digital Baroque opera.

10% towards communication and publicity.

  The Impact


By backing this campaign, you will in effect be helping pave the way for future AR books and helping to re-conceptualize how publishers work with digital artists.
As a contributor you will be kept up to date on the innovative and exciting process of producing this work  - everything from traditional book making to the creation of new augmented reality publishing techniques!
Anteism is working with programmer and inter-active designer Takeshi Mukai to create a tailored application with higher resolution and designed specifically for the Artist book experience.

Take A look at Anteism's first Augmented reality book completed in the spring of 2015, featuring the work of Montreal based gif artist Scorpion Dagger.
 


PERKS!


Anteism has put together an exciting list of donation perks, including the finished Augmented Reality Art Book, original pieces and limited edition print. We assure all of their projects and recognizes their supporters with exciting pieces of art that will be delivered to your address! 







   
    Thank You for supporting Anteism's second Augmented Reality Book project !!!

story:
About me


My names Lianne Lowe, I’m a recent Fine Art Graduate with an insane passion to paint.

After uni I got a little job, moved away from home and started my journey as a freelance artist. I quickly got sucked into reality, a place where you need money to live and you live to make money without actually living at all, where strange lifeless creatures crawl around calling themselves adults whilst working a soul destroying job. I am now one of these creatures.

Help me get back my life loving, ambitious, child like sense of mentality, bring me back to an imaginary reality, one where you can do what you love to do and get by doing it!

My Campaign


I want to create 52 paintings over the space of a year (1 painting a week).

I’m mainly a figurative artist, meaning I have quite possibly an unhealthy obsession with people, the human form, the human mind and anything human related. (I’m not weird I’m just enthusiastic).

I use whatever medium tickles my fancy but mainly oils, acrylics and watercolour. I paint on anything because everything is a canvas in my eyes, but for this project I will no doubt dive into many skips to find wood, cardboard, wall or basically anything else I can get my hands on.

So to sum up:

52 paintings in a year

1 a week

all relating to anything human

done in any medium that I fancy using

done on any material I fancy vandalizing (legally of course)

So essentially at the end of the year I will have a series of paintings I could exhibit in a gallery, but there are 2 main goals.

1.  To eventually gather up enough money to open my own studio, introduce it to the public, collaborate and exhibit with other artists and also teach adult learning classes.

And 2. To rebuild my faith in what I have no doubt in loving but doubt I can make a living from.

I will start painting once i've reached enough money to get art supplies and once I know that people are actually interested in this enough to help a brother out.


What I Need & What You Get

I basically want to paint for a living, and I know i'm probably asking a lot but as a years wage when bills have to be paid, materials have to be bought and food has to be eaten it all adds up!
I'm asking for £5000 (ambitious I know) but this could potentially be the basis of a dream business. 
5000 ÷ 52 = (roughly) £96.15 a week
(the amount I'm hoping for divided by the number of weeks painting)
= £384.60 a month (roughly)
I have a part time job because as you may have noticed i'm maybe a little too ambitious, and rent has to be paid. (plus i've got an ADORABLE little mouth to feed)

(Her name is Caru)
I would love to quit my little job in a factory folding, tagging and bagging clothes to paint full time.
So you guys know I'm doing what i've set out to do and for you to know you're funding something worth funding, I've set up a blog to document every painting.
The link is below.
Also here are some examples of my work!



PERKS

£2 - A Huge thank you!
£5 - A MAHOOSIVE thank you!
£10 - So much love you wouldn't believe! 
£25 - A small, hand drawn thank you picture sent online!
£50 - An A5 original doodle of my choice
£100 - An A5 original watercolour of my choice on watercolour paper
£150 - An A4 original watercolour of my choice on watercolour paper
£250 - An A4 original watercolour on watercolour paper of any animal, you choose!
£500 - An A3 original watercolour portrait of yourself or anyone you want on  watercolour paper!
$600 - An A3 original watercolour of your choice (within reason) on either watercolour paper or cardboard.
£1500 - A 24'' x 30'' oil painting of your choice on canvas or canvas board and you decide what theme I should do on 1 week out of 52
£3000 - Seriously any painting you want, any size smaller than 50 inches on canvas
ADDED PERK!
If you donate £100 pounds or more I will personally invite you to the potential exhibition at the end of the year.
If I haven't reached my goal of £5000 I will still paint and blog with what I have raised and will still appreciate anyone who has funded this.

Why your help is greatly appreciated and how it makes a difference!

To be able to dedicate a year of my life to just painting, to live, breathe and sweat art, would be incredible. Please make me realize I can live doing what I love, because I love it more than anything.
I’ve always wanted to change the world in some way, to make a mark. I don’t want to be famous, just respected for what I do and remembered for doing it. There is ALWAYS a meaning in my figurative art and I want to make people think.
A lot of my work relates to bipolar, depression and other mental illnesses, I want people to be aware that these are real issues that real people struggle with in the real world. I don't want to just paint pretty pictures, I want the people to look at my paintings and realise there's more, there's a story, and it may not be a pretty story but it's one that needs telling.

Challenges


I know a week is a short time to paint anything of high quality and to keep that up for a year when life gets in the way is difficult, but I am a determined son of a gun! If life gets in my way I'll say, 'HEY! LIFE! MOVE OVER! I'M COMING THROUGH!' and i'll give it a look that could kill and shake my fist! 


Other Ways You Can Help

You might not have the money to contribute, but thats fine! I understand money is tight! TRUST ME! But if you have the time and you do want to support this, spread the link and like my Facebook page!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
I need you to help me by donating to my campaign so that I can fulfill my dream of painting:

The Mustangs of Dead Horse Point, Utah

My name is Tuck Contreras and I was born in San Diego, CA.  San Diego used to be a small town with a lot of open country and that is where I started my love affair  with the wild outdoors.  My first exposure to wild horses came while on a hike in the Virginia Hills of Nevada many years ago and I have never forgotten that experience.

My interest in art also started when I was young.  I have been fortunate, as an artist, to create many beautiful things using many types of media.  But it was with and oil paints that I found my muse.  I try to say something important with my art, to create a feeling of discomfort and wonder with my paintings.   The act of creating original art by one person can change the world view of so many.  That is my goal with the painting of this project  which I am going to call "Mustangs of Dead Horse Point". In this work, I want to bring to life the story of the event that took place so many years ago. The painting will memorialize an actual historical event which gave this point above the Grand Canyon its name. I want to show man's wonder, discomfort and even disregard of wild horses, which continues to this day.  

The story goes that horse rustlers used Dead Horse Point to hold groups of wild horses to be culled and sold.  At the narrowest point of the plateau, Dead Horse Point is only 30 yards across, creating a natural corral. The massive cliffs around the point drop 2,000 feet to the floor of the Grand Canyon, thus forming a natural barrier and affording no escape.   For some unknown reason, some of the horses were left corralled on the waterless point where they died of thirst in view of the Colorado River  leaving us only  bones to tell the story of "the mustangs of dead horse point".

Budget for painting:  for the trip to Dead Horse Point....... $2300   (14 days)

Supplies....................$1800

Helicopter for photography..................$2000

Painting ............$6300 

The perks...........$2450............(of coarse this could change)

 Total:  $14850


Tuck.communicatingbydesign.com

American Wild Horse preservation Campaign.org/

www.mustangheritagefoundation.org/

_____________________________________________________________________________

A friend wrote the following poem which was my impetus for this project.


Wild Horses

Remembering the mustangs of Dead Horse Point

 

Towering cloud-drifts sail across blue sky

Ancients, 10,000 years before,

lived here and never brought harm,

beside fairyshrimp you survived on pothole water pools,

before history makers arrived, to drive you to these heights.

They rode north to rope and break your kin,

drove onto this isolated island mesa,

red rock buttes felt you suffer a dull aching pain.

 

Pent on this red island point

overlooking what is even now majestic,

the Canyonlands, thousands of feet below and away,

one by one your herd was broke and tamed,

led to water by gloved hands, past fences, to pastures and paths of Europeans,

to the craven 

untameable mustangs are easily forgotten,

even tangled manes and flashing eyes and split hooves,

they wear no man’s bridle,

unfairly made a left-behind band of broomtails –

in a sky adorned with red arches and great stone pillars

seized up high, Colorado River boundless waters tracing a silver snake far below – 

“you kept your freedom but you didn’t have much time.”

 

Today your corralled end prevades this place

an intensity whinies in the dry air

heavy clear skies push down

and pinon and juniper arch up on hindquarters and call out for water,

empty space hung beyond each cliff still presses in from the East, and West.

Exposed southern drop-off, demanded you retreat,

forced by your natural instincts in directions

that ended your living near a barrier made by man.

Your thirst for freedom is here today.

 

Those who listen recognize your ghost herd – you toss heads and drum on ground

where you once ached to be quenched,

you impart an emotional vertigo,

and your dark circumstances tempt me to throw my scarf skyward and ride

head-long into the chasm.

           

My memory of here is now forever bound to your loss, to Thelma and Louise, to

untamed spirits pent by wickedness and waste.

If we were to perished here, then or now,

we still remain as we ever were, so 

“let’s do some living after we die.”

 

 

By Jameson K. Alexander
